156332117.review:
Im not any fancy reviewer, however I am a gamer and consumer like the rest of you kindly requesting you offer a few minutes to hear what I have to share.
Let me start being brief; Larian Studios has blown me away.

For some context of who I am and where I come from? I have loved the divinity games for a few years now and was hyped for them being announced to make the successor to Balldur's Gate I & II. 
I am a also a Gamemaster and have been for Dungeons & Dragons nearly fourteen years now. I've been in the DnD sphere of games and RPGs since the beginnings of 2nd Edition when I was really young. I have experienced each system across the board, numerous titles accompanying the array of editions published. 

To speak of BG III itself; What Larian did here not only blew away my expectations as a D&D experience, but honored many of the greatest markers of D&D and RPG (and CRPG) history that can be found as D&D has evolved over its many years. What Larian has done is created the perfect gateway into Baldur's gate and older classics with the fervor and easy accessibility of 5th edition D&D. 

Baldur's Gate III has done the impossible, this is the perfect place to begin if you never played D&D and would like to feel what its like or if you just cannot access a D&D group and still would like to play. BG III utilizes the best parts of the game system and highlights them with an exemplary immersive experience that showcases many old classics that came before in the same curated heart and care in their creation years ago.
Even still, it rests at a comfortable price with an innumerable amounts of replay-ability at your fingertips with one price tag. No micro-transactions, no subscriptions, no catches. BG III was made for you and I; both fans and gamers each. A true testaments to the games that came before and were adored for the respect and care for not only the game, but those who are playing their game. 

Larian Studios have been folk I have chosen to watch closely a while now, and I have zero hesitancy today they are one of the developers to keep even closer eyes on. They are a relic of Gaming seemingly lost and excruciating difficult to find in the western markets today, and they have my full adoration and respect.

Baldur's Gate III is in a very small and shrinking category each passing year. One of the few games released in recent years I found worth my time and money as it was a full packaged deal that truly captivate me and have me inspired with hope to finally sit down and enjoy where the sky is the limit.

156150948.review:
[h1] [i] I am once again reminded why I am proud to be a gamer. [/i] [/h1]

[h2] Roleplaying Elements [/h2]
There have been many great games that truly put you in the driver’s seat without relying on the illusion of control, but Baldur’s Gate 3 has managed to surprise me in this matter. Almost every action you take has consequences. Sometimes, the order of your actions might determine the future as well. This extremely enhances the replayability. The game rewards thoughtful actions and truly allows for role-playing, a term that is sadly misused in many modern games.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
The overall gameplay is super rewarding because you constantly see the outcomes of your actions, both in and out of combat. Plus, a great build variety that offers tons of fun as heck experimenting and replayability.

[h2] Voice acting and dialogue [/h2]
Simply marvelous. Every single voice actor did such an amazing job that you can immediately tell each and every one of them did what they did with great passion. Each line of dialogue flows effortlessly, thanks to the amazing writing.

[h2] Story and characters [/h2]
Even though the dialogue is great, the story is one of the weakest parts of Baldur’s Gate 3. It doesn’t hurt the overall quality of the game; however, it is quite clichéd. Nevertheless, combined with a diverse and compelling cast of characters and deep roleplaying mechanics, the story is overall interesting and worthwhile.

[h2] Sound & Music [/h2]
A soundtrack that will surely stick with me for the rest of my life. Hearing “Down by the River” for the first time in character creation and “Song of Balduran” in Act 3 have become some of my favorite moments in gaming. Going back to camp after a hard-fought battle and hearing all these fantastic songs while chatting with your companions—now that is indeed special.

[h2] UI/UX [/h2]
Pretty concise UI that is easy to comprehend and navigate. It is particularly important in a game like this, so I think it is worth mentioning.

[h2] CO-OP experience [/h2]
We played the game 2-player coop, and I gotta say, it was easily the best multiplayer experience I’ve ever had. Super smooth coop interactions and no “host-guest complications” like in many other games. It was a blast debating which dialogue options to go with, who to side with, who to betray, and so on. It truly was a special experience in that regard.

[h2] Bugs [/h2]
A game as big as this naturally has bugs. Acts 1 and 2 were almost perfect; however, Act 3 annoyed me a bit with the bugs. Bugs such as some cutscenes not loading, some enemies not taking any actions, visual inconsistencies, etc. Bugs in Act 3 are worth mentioning, even though they are not game-breaking and didn’t really affect my enjoyment.

[h2] Final thoughts [/h2]
In my 17 years of gaming, I have only had a few experiences that are comparable to Baldur’s Gate 3. I am truly grateful that I got to experience a masterpiece of this caliber.

156505567.review:
I haven't finished it yet, and I don't expect to finish it any time soon. Act 1 took me about 50 hours, Act 2 is supposed to be 10-20 hours longer, and I haven't even got to Act 3 yet.

It's the best game I've played in a long time. Best single player RPG since Dragonage Origins. (Also supports multi-player, which works quite well)

It has an amazing cast of voice actors. The core companions are really well-written, and all have their quests to explore, many of which are linked to the main story.

Gameplay is really engaging. You can save freely whenever you want, even mid-conversation.

It's based on the D&D 5 ruleset, but they made some necessary changes (like no prestidigitation spell).

One thing to be aware of - Long Resting. A bunch of cutscenes that advance the story will happen in the camp, when you rest. For this reason, I suggest resting quite often. You can also go to the camp and 'end the day' without taking a long rest to get the story stuff.

156495871.review:
Baldur's Gate 3 is a magnificent journey that immerses players in a world of magic, mystery, and mayhem. From the very beginning, the game captures your attention with its stunning visuals, engaging storytelling, and intricate character development. Larian Studios has truly outdone themselves in creating an experience that pays homage to the beloved Baldur's Gate series while introducing fresh and innovative gameplay mechanics.

The first two acts of the game are nothing short of brilliant. The attention to detail in the environments, the diverse array of characters, and the complex narrative choices make for a truly unforgettable experience. The combat system is both strategic and dynamic, offering a perfect blend of classic RPG elements and modern gameplay.

The character creation and progression system in Baldur's Gate 3 are exceptional, allowing players to mold their characters into unique personalities with their own strengths, weaknesses, and backstories. The companions you encounter throughout your journey are well-written and add depth to the overall narrative, with each having their own quirks and motivations.

However, where Baldur's Gate 3 falters is in its final act. The journey to the climax is nothing short of spectacular, but as the story reaches its pinnacle, the experience becomes marred by a noticeable lack of polish. Quests become less refined, and the overall level of detail in both the narrative and the environment seems to take a hit.

While the final act still manages to deliver a satisfying conclusion to the overarching story, the lack of polish is undeniable. Some plotlines feel rushed, and there are instances where the game's performance dips, breaking the otherwise immersive experience. It's disappointing to see such a fantastic journey conclude with a slightly tarnished finale.

Despite these shortcomings, Baldur's Gate 3 remains a must-play for any RPG enthusiast. The majority of the game is a testament to Larian Studios' dedication to quality, and the final act, although unpolished, doesn't diminish the overall enjoyment of the game. With the promise of updates and improvements, there's hope that the developers will address these issues, ensuring that Baldur's Gate 3 stands as a shining example of modern RPG excellence.

So yes it's amazing, just get it if you enjoy Fantasy RPGs.
But best game ever?
Right so I'm not going to sing it's praises, as everyone else has done this job.
I am going to list how it could have been better, and why it's maybe not the best game ever. Because I can:
1) Level Cap Limitations. Yes I've read the guff online of people defending the limit of 12, but they could easily have allowed you to level up to 15-16, without ruining the enjoyment of the game. Once you are in act 3 and you hit 12, you still have loads to do. Although I found most fights fun at 12, a few more levels, would have stopped me having to do a bit of cheese (and this was only on balanced mode, mind). If there are certain overpowered spells, remove or nerf them. They have basically done this already anyway. Dispel Magic anyone?
2) Inventory and Storage system. It's such a faff, yes I've seen worse, but I've also seen better. One chest for storage in your camp with limited sort options. No stacking of the same items, so many dagger slots!
3) The Aggro is too random. In the Goblin camp, you get into it with one group. Every Goblin in the world turns on you. In a prison you break someone out, kill all the guards and you are flirting with their colleagues at the top of the stairs, whilst the escaped prisoner is stood next to you. As the Goblin Camp is your first experience. It restricts experimentation, as you try and avoid combat in situations that are valid options, as you expect every man and their dog to turn on you.
4) It's too woke. Only joking. I thought it was fine, you snowflakes.

156486317.review:
I have finally finished the game with my party and I don't think there ever was a game I have played in my life that made me go and say, "I really want a DLC or expansion for this." The game is amazing and has set a new standard for AAA games, the world is carefully crafted, Its feels lived in, its relaxing and soothing in a weird way. The only other game that made me feel this way when walking around it was probably Kingdom come: Deliverance just because of how realistic it feels, Realistic in a sense that it feels like you could very well see something similar in real life, people going about their day, working their jobs, doing their routines, I feel like that's that something that is rarely captured and done well in RPG's or is something that is simply overlooked and barely given any attention to by the developers.

The voice actors and actresses also did an amazing job as well as the writing team, each character was incredibly interesting thanks to them. None of the main characters are boring carbon copies of each other, they all have their own personalities, mannerisms, they all have deep stories that you end up uncovering more and more as you progress through the game making them feel even more fleshed with each part of the game, and the voice actors and actresses did an amazing job translating all of that into their voices. 

The writing is outstanding for both the NPC's and the Playable characters, The writing got me immersed in my characters to the point when I was picking dialogue I wasn't looking for the option with the best outcome but what MY character would say, whereas in other games like Skyrim, Kingdom come or fallout I would often do the opposite. The character creator is also really good, every time I created a new character for a different play through I would always end up building lore of that character in my head, I never wanted to just make a character that just looks cool, I also wanted them to have a story prior to the events of the game.

If you don't know whether you should buy the game or not because you might not end up liking, trust me, give it a go. You have two hours of playtime to refund the game if you don't end up liking it, or you can get the game through other means although I urge you to buy it if you're interested in it and have the money to do so. I have never played a game in this genre prior to Baldurs gate 3, My main interest in games were competitive multiplayer games such as counter strike, rainbow six siege, call of duty and I have the hours to back it up on my profile, *2800 hours on counter strike, 1800 hours on R6 siege.* I ended up loving it and it caused me and my friends to gain massive interest in DnD to the point where we're planning on setting up a campaign at some point. 

Baldurs gate 3 has set a new standard for games, I think it's unfair to expect indie games to be held to the same standard as Baldurs gate 3. But AAA games SHOULD be and NEED to be held to the standard of Baldurs gate 3, it's ridiculous that these massive studios are releasing broken half completed games for full price, some of them having gold or special editions which cost even more and rarely add anything of value to the game, not to mention how many times the studios attack or ridicule people when they go to point the obvious flaws a game has or even when providing constructive criticism.

I very rarely write reviews for games, And the ones that I did end up writing were mostly Meme/Joke reviews not to be taken seriously. This is probably the first Proper review that I have written about a game because of how much I enjoyed my time with it.

156679574.review:
In our golden years, my husband and I found an unexpected source of joy and reconnection: the classic role-playing game, "Baldur's Gate." We've been married for over 40 years, and with our children grown up and out of the house, we found ourselves drifting apart, each lost in our own routines.

It all changed when our grandson introduced us to "Baldur's Gate." Initially, I was skeptical. The idea of two elderly delving into a fantasy world of wizards and warriors seemed absurd. But my husband, always the adventurer at heart, was intrigued. Together, we decided to give it a try, thinking it would be a humorous story to share with our friends.

The first time we played, it was a comedy of errors. I couldn't tell an elf from an orc, and my husband's wizard spent more time accidentally casting spells on himself than on the enemies. But as we fumbled through the game, something wonderful happened. We started laughing together like we hadn't in years. Each gaming session became a new adventure, filled with both in-game challenges and fits of laughter from our clumsy mistakes.

As we journeyed through the rich story and complex puzzles of "Baldur's Gate," we began to work as a team, just like in the early days of our marriage. We strategized together, celebrated our victories, and consoled each other in our defeats. The game became our nightly ritual, a time where we could escape to a fantastical world and reconnect.

Playing "Baldur's Gate" rekindled something in our relationship that we thought we had lost. We found new topics to talk about, reminiscing about our in-game adventures during the day. Our shared interest in the game led to other shared activities, reigniting the spark that brought us together all those years ago.

"Baldur's Gate" became more than just a game for us; it was a gateway to rediscovering each other. It showed us that no matter how long you've been together, there are always new and exciting ways to connect and grow as a couple. Our evenings in front of the computer, exploring the Sword Coast, became cherished moments, a testament to the enduring power of love and laughter.

158128938.review:
I played a bit of early access a year ago or so. So when I started playing this game in full release, I already knew it was going to be pretty good. But the full release was far better than my own expectations. This already is most likely one of my favourite games and I have yet to explore other possibilities ingame. 

The finale of every act feels so rewarding after all your efforts. The details in every zone are amazing, i found myself exploring every single room and corner of the world and collecting books, notes and other papers full of lore. 

My favourite Act was definitely Act III but not to say Act I and II were bad. It was because of the previous Acts that Act III made sense and felt so satisfying. 

My favourite arc (if you can call it that) was House of Hope or Raphael's arc. I'm sure most of the players agree they enjoyed his song during his "boss fight". This poetic devil named Raphael is one my favourite characters. I think he and Mizora truly represent what we know of devils. (Nice detail on 666HP). Hope was also cool, wholesome and funny. How am I not gonna save her during my evil run...

My favourite companion is predictable I know, but yes Shadowheart and I am not talking about romance (only). Every character really developed during the story and trying to solve their own personal problems while fighting together to solve their common problem, the illithid tadpoles stuck in their brains and saving the world from the Absolute (or not depending on your choices). Most characters (even NPCs) have a story, a personality, a opinion of their own, So sometimes, if you are making certain decisions, you might not just be affecting the main or secondary characters but also a "random" NPC walking by.

Cinematics were amazing and well planned. I used screenshot a lot!
I hope the voice actors of this game were payed good. The characters felt so real with their emotions and personalities. The team who worked on expressions and body language helped a lot to give the characters life of course.

A few extras I feel the need to say:
Shadow isles was the hardest part imo. It did indeed felt how hard it was to live in those conditions and the amount of destruction in the various places of the map caused by the curse. But again all that to satisfyingly reward us with a lot.
Karlach's ending made me want to cry no matter the ending you chose (cry from sadness, relief or joy)
I'm not sure if I missed stuff in the previous Acts, but Act III felt the longest one. It was probably intended.

I think thats all? Thanks for reading and for the patience!
Sorry if bad english...

157147380.review:
TL;DR 

A masterpiece Roleplaying Game, a good restitution of D&d Baldur's Gate setting, an extremely crappy, extremely twisted 5e system "transcription".

If you are looking for a faithful "Dungeon & Dragons 5e" experience, skip this one without regret and grab Solasta Crown of the Magister instead. Story is mediocre and looks are 10 years behind (they didn't have the same budget nor time so couldn't work miracles) but at least the combat is solid.

If you don't care about getting "5e representative experience", then this is the one game you can and should play before most others.

=== Detailed review ===
So finally it's here the long-awaited game after 2 years of early access. 
There is no doubt it's a gem overall, but there are a few caveats to be aware of still.
For most people these would be inconsequential though.

== Story ==
11/10. Yup, no mistake. Didn't finish the game yet to be honest, but could already witness from several parallel games with different groups how far they went into providing decisive choices and consequences ending up with vastly different narratives (we're not speaking of a few secondary characters being alive or dead or choosing between A, A' and A'' endings here, but entire chunks of stories being tossed apart, the destiny of Baldur's Gate - and your own - being like different dimensions).

== Narration ==
11/10. Yep, still no mistake. Not only do you have, literally, a thousand different NPCs in the game, ALL of them have voice-acting. The "worst" part is... Only about half of them have interesting bits of informations or quests to offer. "Only". xd
By the way, no worries, actors were paid well this time, and it feels. Intonations and rythms are really "inplace" with what's being said, so you're like, watching a movie, except you actually have impact on their destinies this time.

== Aesthetics (lights, photography, layout, characters, effects, animations) ==
9/10. You'll travel through a great variety of lanscapes each providing an unique identity. Places have been designed with three dimensions in mind and it feels, while not the magnitude of a Breath of the Wild you'll stop quite often to appreciate the design.

Chracters are well-modelled, effects are nice... Nothing much to say here, it's worth of a 2023 AAA.

== Music ==
7/10. Does its job well, but apart from the main theme, I doubt I'll remember any of those 10 years from now. 
But hey it's always something very personal here.
From a purely "technical" point of view, music is always matching the situation in terms of instruments, tempos and "narrative style".

== UX ==
3/10. A real catastrophe here, although counter-intuitively it's a bit better on gamepad since you can "organize" (painfully) all your abilities in different rings.
But overall, and in spite of a few nice ideas like different ways to sort things and ways to exchange items... I've never been that lost in an interface. EVEN WHEN PLAYING THE SAME "SIMPLE" CHARACTER (aka not a Druid with dozen of different spells available) SPANNING DOZEN OF HOURS.
The main problem is dual: the fact the person who chose/designed icons must have been blind. And the fact there are so many things that clutter your "action bars" dynamically. 
They tried to resolve it after the fact by providing tabs which filter by class or by action type but even then the icons are far too small, far too simple in design and far too similar from one another for you to get your way through. Ah and bonus point: their position will change too. Obviously.
They should have taken a lesseon, or rather a semester of it, from Tactical Adventures. It's far less shiny but it's 100x times more efficient.

== Gameplay (combat apart) ==
8/10: you have exploration, you have social confrontation with lots of options depending on your background/class/characteristics/reputation, you have puzzles, every animal and corpse (nearly) have things to say... 
There are a lot they did neatly here, and they grasped the essence of D&d as far as exploration and social pillars go...
HOWEVER...

== Gameplay (Combat) ==
5/10. Yup. I stand by it. Not that it's too simple or bland mind you. It's because they went so far in trying to "bring their touch" they ended up with a Frankenstein of balance.
Artificially try to play the closest to Authentic 5e, you'll probably have a hard day or possibly get wrecked. 
Lean into their changes to class, their additions of "surfaces" and "stackable effects", their "story-born powers", the "physics applied to fantasy game yet every character jumps farther than the best olympic" elements? You can range from frustrating experience to insipid "stomp everything" one, and everything in between. It's like the mess of a 3year old child taking all toys together to throw them around in chaos.

And in parallel to that they brought some nerfs that are, even with the best goodwill of the world, completely voided of any logic or reason. Which for some even go straight against their apparent goal design of "enjoy the powercreep and have fun experimenting various combinations".

This is probably a perfect ground for people who like spending dozen hours comparing equipment and character combinations "a la diablo" before even playing. But this brings a completely heterogeneous experience from one game to another, and from one player to another.

Things are even worsened by their other stupidest idea, "simultaneous turns". Which could have actually been great... IF YOU COULD REWIND. 
Countless times did I see wasted resources and turns because players don't really coordinate and end up wasting each other's time.

Really, the biggest disappointment of the game for me, and it didn't even miss the mark by much. They just needed to respect all 5e rules while keeping their level and encounter design. And it would have been perfect.

157587041.review:
[h1]Preface[/h1]
TLDR: Baldur's Gate is a game made by a talented, passion-driven team and deserves it's Overwhelmingly Positive score. However, it is not for everyone. Consider this a Mixed review.

[h1]Is this for you?[/h1]
For context, I am a huge fan of tactical strategy games, turn based RPGs, CRPGs, and narrative heavy games. I have all that qualities of someone who should love this game, at least in theory.

In my eyes, it's not quite Baldur's Gate enough to be considered a natural continuation of the franchise. Simultaneously, it's not freeform enough to be considered Divinity: Original Sin 3. It's like an awkward mixture of both with modified DnD 5e rules thrown in. In some areas, it works quite well, but the vast majority of the fusion feels half-baked.

My theory is that the high score comes from three camps:
[list]
[*] People who have never played the Divinity Franchise and like DnD
[*] Larian super fans
[*] Gamers who are starved for good games by the lack of new good quality AAA titles and general bad business practices from them.
[/list]


If you're like me on the other hand, I don't typically lean on AAA titles to maximize my enjoyment out of gaming. I have played previous Larian games before and this doesn't come off as much different than their previous entry, Divinity: Original Sin 2.

[h1]I heard you like dice rolls...[/h1]
Let's talk about the most obvious low-hanging fruit: The dice roll mechanic. The implementation of the mechanic is over-saturated. You roll for most things, even if you're adept at whatever skill you are trying to check for. This trivializes the entire mechanic and also shows a lack of fundamental understanding of why you even roll dice on skill checks in the first place. You typically roll for things that are [b]not[/b] part of your character's core skills, unless the particular check is more difficult than average or it presents a clear and present danger/importance to the party. 

Instead, there are a ton of 10 or under level skill checks thrown in on most things, especially locks. If you are playing with a rogue (or bring Astarion), you are going to succeed on the vast majority of these unlocks. It seems as if the simple solution is to bypass the check for rolls if you have modifiers that would only cause failure in the case of a 1. That would at least take out 80% of the cruft associated with trivial rolls.

On the same token, let's talk about more difficult rolls and their underwhelming results. Most of these more difficult rolls are for dialogue options, and these are difficult even if you have proficiency in them. Only rarely have I had a difficult check result in something that changed the outcome of a predetermined event, but it is inexcusable to not have ALL incredibly difficult checks result in some kind of a boon to the player if they succeed. Using two examples: There's an intimidation check you can succeed for one of the boss encounters in Act 2. When you succeed that, the leader convinces his followers to kill themselves. This... feels awesome and makes the coming fight much easier. In the same Act, you fight another boss in which you have to succeed two difficult checks in a row. The last one is nearly impossible to get without tons of extra modifiers or a perfect 20. If you do succeed you get... more dialogue and no changes to the fight what-so-ever. All this does is punish players who want to get the most out of the story by leaving certain outcomes gated by luck.

[h1]The Rest is history[/h1]
I understand what they were trying to do with short rests and long rests, but it could have been implemented in a way that makes sense to both game flow and 5e rules.

The core problem is this: The combat system encourages you to go into encounters, be sparing with some of your more powerful abilities and spells until you really need them and do 'soft-resets' by short resting so you can be ready for more encounters before you have to inevitably return to camp. This can work in theory, but there are a two major factors working against this system.

Firstly, there aren't a lot of trivial encounters in the game. While there are definitely some, the vast majority of combat encounters have lots of enemies, characters getting bursted down to critically low health, or require you to dip into some of your limited abilities to be efficient. While you can just short rest and continue, you severely reduce your likelihood of success if your characters are at low/mid health for the next encounter. I did try to limit long resting as much as possible, but then realized that there wasn't much point in doing that as you end up drowning in camping supplies the more you progress. Short resting was a simple 'push your luck and continue' option.

Second, healing is almost pointless in this game outside of resting. Some of your stronger heals, even when upcasting them, tend to barely restore the HP of the character you're targeting. It's far better to use the limited spell slots for a more offensive/utility driven spell. Even the group party heal you get out of combat sucks. I did find one potential use for healing (though I admit, I've never played a healing character in DnD and didn't know this was legal) and that's bringing up a character that is 'down', performing saving throws. My thought was that they can only be healed if brought up from that downed state by using the 'help' action. Turns out, I was using my heals incorrectly the vast majority of my play through. Ah well.

[h1]Play the story [strike]you[/strike] I want to play, or else![/h1]
This is a personal gripe and I'm sure different characters will yield different results but I want to say that I played Gale the way 'I' thought his story should play out. I did not know that by doing so, [spoiler]it would prematurely end my game[/spoiler] and despite the 'sort-of' resolution, it was unsatisfying. But what was even more unsatisfying was that in order to continue, I had to replay that scene and just pretend that Gale had different motivations. It begs the question: why even present that as a choice to the player, while also giving tidbits into his background and personal motivations, just to punish the player by following through with it? I'm not expecting a narrative epic with thousands of branching pathways depending on responses, but it seems like a design oversight. Maybe it's just an example of 'Larian humor' but it removed a lot of my motivation to continue.

What's worse, your own character's motivations as your approach act 3 become so disjointed with the story up until that point, it makes me wish I accepted what I got early and stopped there. It seems to be typical with Larian that the story starts strong and ends up significantly weaker the further you go on. It happened with Divinity: Original Sin 2 and I'm not shocked it's here as well.


[h1]Positives[/h1]
That's a whole lot of negatives so why am I claiming this a 'mixed' review instead of a outright negative one?

Despite this game not being for me, it is very clearly made with love for a specific audience in mind. Most of my criticism are not game breaking and depending on your character selections, you may not even encounter the problems I did. Still, you don't need my review to convince you. There are clearly a vast majority of gamers who did enjoy their experiences. I'm only offering my perspective to sway those who may be on the fence.

All-in-all, using the combat system as an analogy: You have advantage on a 93% chance of liking this game. Probability says you 'will' like this game, but don't be surprised if it's a miss for you. That's just how things play out sometimes.

[i]Should mention that the original review went more in-depth into some areas and had to be cut to meet the current text character restriction. Comments are open for further discourse.[/i]

[b]Rating:[/b] ★★★★★ - Amazing

	- Mass Effect style conversations.

	- Sharp, witty, and emotionally resonant dialogue.
	- Meaningful character creation and player choices that impact the story, adding replay value.

	- Require modern day graphics card and CPU to run (Gaming PC from the past 4-6 years).
	- Visually stunning with attention to detail in environments, character designs, and special effects.
	- Alive and dynamic world that enhances immersion
	- Remarkable graphics contribute to storytelling and gameplay, creating a captivating experience

[b]Before you Play: [/b]
	- Experiment with different playstyles and choices to appreciate narrative and mechanics depth.

156505245.review:
In short, would I recommend this game, yes......
but it has issues, quite a bit actually, but let's not get ahead of ourselves.

The story is a great piece of writing full of twists, turns and subversions of expectations. The reveals, complexity of characters and plot is trully something that amazed me here. It also deals well with hard dilemas and choices, making the most important ones not always beeing between good and evil, but whether you will give up one valuable thing over another with meaninglful sacrifices. The companions and the main cast have so much personality that even if most of them fited into classic RPG archetypes still felt unique in their own right.
All of that great scenes are, to my displeasure, paired with surprising lack of some small dialouges between characters building our bonds and trying to side with one over another. I understand that it is a result of the 3d cutscenes that makes creating a many shorter scenes more costly but without them we have quite empty reputation system that makes green lizard want to get into my pants without me realising why and creating the infamous sex speedrun. Another shortcoming of the story is a underdeveloped main antagonist that suffered because of lesser villans having much more screen time and the need for a game to have more flexibility, still it could have been done better.

Going to gameplay I must praise the enemy encounters, each of them unique with its gimmicks and enemies that require at least some thought from the player and allowing for intresting or straight up funny strategies. The balance of the game is so well done that I, on my first playthrough, was able to beat the hard mode of the game without special powers or much minmaxing and seating 30 minutes on an encounter, only reloading individual ones maximum like 3 times. I of course sometimes run upon a fight way too hard for mee for a time but the game always allows you to go back, gear up with powerful consumables, and try again.
Buuuut it does not mean that the system is flawless, melee fighters doing otk on you characters and first strike capabilites being difference between life and death are problems, but they can too be used by the player, so it cancels for difficulty purposes but still left me a bad taste in my mouth.
Other issues of this part are mosty related to lack of quality of life, too large hitboxes of some enemies, messed up pathing that only sometimes avoids triggering traps and other perils, quite easy to get yourself hit by opportunity attack if you clicked wrong, you want to see or target something on the other floor, frick you. There are solutions to all this problems, do it manually by the means of turn mode and careful observation or just knowing when the broken systems are working and learning their rules because it is not hard to deal with it if you know what is going on, but their inconsistancy is still the thong that drives me mental. One time I could avoid the minefield and deal with encounter with minimal friction and the other time I would accidently explode the entire minefield that I knew that was there and then end up in a fight were my allies just decided it was time to die for nothing. And the finall straw was that the programmers messed up the most basic change giving algorithm that is the camp supplies, like it is the first thing that you learn in the IT classes, and still they couldn't do it right and what is even weirder, is that if you click the second time on the button it somehow works correctly!?! 
I will not even talk about some dialogue bugs, circa 10 crashes throughout entire playthrough and some soft lock with one mod I had that happend because of a minor hotfix in game, like the code of this game is propably a huge mess of spaghetti.

At least visual and musical teams done their job well and I trully enjoyed both scenery, models and soundtrack. All of that on my almost outdated graphics card without much lags or truly low quality graphics. I must admit that in bigger cities the game tended to work much slower but it did not ruin the experience.

All in all the game is trully something amazing and woth recommendation but it should have remained in early acces for another year or at least invest more into their programming team. So If you are not sure you want to buy it I would recommend waitng another half a year or so for some greater sale.

156144091.review:
Baldur's Gate 3 immerses players in an authentic RPG journey, featuring a compelling narrative, remarkable characters, and a truly captivating world to explore. Acts 1 and 2 are intricately designed, offering immersive role-playing experiences. However, Act 3 encounters a bit of quest log bloat, turning the adventuring experience into more of a checklist, with most quests inevitably leading to combat. However, Larian does an exceptional job at delivering a rich narrative that grapples with numerous story threads that are eventually skillfully woven together by the end of act 3.

Despite its virtues, the game is not without flaws. Overwhelming DnD 5e mechanics, a departure from the traditional DnD experience, pose a challenge at times. In BG3, the world is a sandbox, sometimes casting players in the dual roles of both Dungeon Master and adventurer, creating a rich yet occasionally overwhelming experience.

Nonetheless, BG3 distinguishes itself as an exceptional RPG experience. In an era saturated with live-service games and questionable monetization practices, it remains a valuable gem, delivering a genuine and fulfilling role-playing adventure. We are fortunate to have such a game in today's gaming landscape.

157945423.review:
With the sheer amount of [i]video game[/i] available in Baldur's Gate 3, there's a lot to say.

[h3]TL;DR[/h3]
[b]The incredible attention to detail in this game makes it feel like (almost) everything you do has a real impact on the world you're in. This is an adventure that will stick with you long after the end. One that you can go back to multiple times and have wholly different experiences with on each pass, or compare with others who have played.[/b]

[b]Not only the story of the character you choose to play, but that of your band of misfits and many others you meet along the way are (almost) all equally as compelling.[/b]

[b]Between all of the different party compositions and build variety for every character (including multiclassing), you can approach everything the game throws at you in (almost) any way you can think of.[/b]

[b][u][i]Very high recommend.[/i][/u][/b]


[h3]The long version.[/h3]
I thoroughly enjoyed (almost) all of my time with BG3. The world, the characters, the story, the side stories, the combat - they're all very well done and show a clear love for the project put in from the developers, voice actors, and everyone involved in making the game.
I've had an eye on BG3 since it's been in Early Access and have been looking forward to going through it.

The mechanics of the game definitely feel fair. 
The dialogue and skill checks make sense for the situations they come up in. Seeing the results, both good and bad, and dealing with the consequences of these checks definitely added to the feel that the world is being shaped by you and your choices.

The game immediately hooks you with the opening hours. Just about everything in Act 1 is put together masterfully.
Exploring every inch of the wilderness and finding all there is to find, while recruiting your companions along the way, is a blast.
Here is where the world really feels alive, with so many quests and requests that tie together in a natural way. Lots of characters whose fates are tied to your actions and lots that get you thinking "I bet I'll see them again later" once you wrap up whatever they had going on.
Heading to camp after completing a big quest to hear everyone's takes on what just happened is always fun.

However, there are a lot of "(almost)"s above and in the TL;DR, and the reasons for those show a lot more in the 2 later acts.
The game absolutely retains all of the good in Act 2 - massive areas to explore, hidden areas that can be completely missed, new quests to complete, new characters to meet. But there are definitely signs of content that was started up and then altered or altogether removed during the Early Access development for whatever reason.
Again, nothing major or gamebreaking, there were just a couple of times where I had the thought of "oh, I thought they were going to do something more with that".

During act 3 is where my enjoyment decreased quite a bit, for a number of reasons. Definitely not to the point of wanting to stop going through the game, but the amount of issues that appeared added up over time.
Act 3 as a whole just felt generally less well put together. I was surprised at the amount of technical issues I encountered here. Bugs like quest markers on the map not updating properly, or being locked into a dialogue with the camera pointed at the wall and not being able to choose any options are small things - easily remedied by reloading the save. Except when your last save is from 30+ minutes ago...
Performance also noticeably degrades here and things like animations in cutscenes bug out or shake in a distracting way.
Of course, bugs and performance issues like this won't happen for everyone, and some players may not even notice or care about them.

However, what will affect most all players are bugs relating to quest progression. Without getting into spoilers I did encounter a few quests where they either would not progress correctly, or, somehow, progressing [i]too much[/i].
On not progressing correctly - a few quests had a lot of trouble with some objectives being done out of order, which struck me as odd here since other quests earlier in the game (as well as other games) typically accounted for things like this. This led to needing to search for fixes online from others who ended up in similar spots and going through tedious steps like dropping specific items in certain areas and picking them back up to force the progression to continue.
On progressing too much - one particular important questline for a main companion appeared to complete for me much earlier than it was supposed to, giving me a lot of information that was supposed to be revealed later in the game.

Larian is actively still putting out patches and hotfixes for the game though, so I don't doubt that issues like these will likely be addressed and corrected in the future.

Still, overall, Baldur's Gate 3 is a [i][b][u]fantastic[/u][/b][/i] video game. Honestly one of the best in recent years and it can definitely be classified as a "must-play".

Right or wrong, BG3 always has an avenue for a wonderfully detailed and successful campaign. The only other games remotely close to this genre that I have played in years past are Skyrim and Fallout 4. BG3 trumps them all.

This isn't just 2023's Game of the Year. I'd argue it might be game of the decade.
S/O Larian for converting me into an RPG nerd. Hopefully it results in my IRL brain development.

11/10. Would Recommend.

156948348.review:
This is a spoiler-free review!!

I am 70 hours in and still firmly in Act 1 - this game is HUGE. it's gorgeous, expansive, and the attention to detail is unparalleled compared to anything else I've played. I don't usually play games with turn-based combat (except Pokemon but that's a different kettle of fish) so that was a bit of a learning curve, but start on the easiest difficulty while you're learning, and you'll do just fine. You can change the difficulty at any time - a welcome accessibility feature - among many many other customisable settings to help your experience run smoothly and fit your individual needs.

The characters in this game feel alive. The voice acting is just on another level, and there's hundreds, maybe thousands, of hours of voice-acted lines that bring the game to life and allow you to really connect with the characters. Each of the main characters has their own individual backstory, personality, vulnerabilities and strengths, all of which you get to learn naturally throughout the progression of the game, with thoughtfully timed cut-scenes and interesting dialogue. Your choices really do matter too, you feel like you're actually making an impact on how the story unfolds.

Fundamentally, this game's main mechanics are based heavily upon Dungeons and Dragons 5e, and if you're worried about not knowing how to play D&D, let me reassure you that you do not need to know how to play D&D to play BG3. In fact, I've learnt a lot about how to play D&D through playing BG3! There are of course differences between them but it's certainly a nice starting point.

I genuinely, wholeheartedly have not felt so passionate about a game since I first played Skyrim. It's visually stunning, the story is compelling, and the characters feel alive. There's plenty of side-questing, and thorough exploration is handsomely rewarded throughout the game - that's why I'm 70hrs in and still in Act 1 of 3! Obviously everyone has their own play styles, and all I can say is this game fits mine beautifully. I feel like I could write a whole essay on what I love about this game to try and convince you to play it, but instead, I implore you to stop wasting time reading this, and just go and experience it for yourself! Genuinely 10/10, would VERY highly recommend.

[h1]Possibly the best designed game, ever.[/h1]

One thing that will come across to you as you play Baldur's Gate 3 is the sheer staggering amount of effort that the developers have put into it. The length and complexity of each act is almost beyond comprehension. 

Quite often nowadays in games, you have NPCs that are purely for decoration, no more than set dressing in the same way a cardboard box is placed next to a dumpster in a city's back street. Baldur's Gate 3 says fuck all that, and makes every NPC you come across have some kind of purpose, whether you know it or not.

This is on top of incredibly robust interaction systems, meaning if you can think of a way to engage with a situation, you can probably do it. A common selling point of games, especially since the Xbox 360/PS3 era, was the slogan "Play it [i]your[/i] way!", and Baldur's Gate 3 is almost the only truthful manifestation of that phrase. You really can engage with it in anyway you see fit. The game doesn't stop you, it makes you live with the consequences.

It has issues, like the pacing and performance towards the end of the game, and honestly the UI could do with a once-over to make it a little more readable, but overall this is a fundamental achievement in game design, and will live on for generations to come. This is [i]the[/i] definitive CRPG experience, right now.

158175338.review:
This game is a fantastic representation of a high fantasy, mature D&D campaign. The interactions and scenarios the developers built into every conceivable event makes the gameplay unique and exciting for both video game and pen and paper enthusiasts. 

That said, this game has a steep learning curve. The tutorial and early encounters assume the player has a working knowledge of how D&D 5e mechanics function, a familiarity with action economy, and how to balance classes to make a functional party. The Balanced difficulty has many enemies utilizing the environment and skill check actions not made clear as options to the player. Once you understand and have a master of these things the game is an extremely rewarding and enjoyable experience; until you do so, however, it can be a grueling grind. 

Overall, I highly recommend the game. I encourage anyone interested in it to research the class they want to play ahead of starting, and see how it may interact with the early party members you'd have access to in Act 1.

158169332.review:
Being a fan of Tabletop RPGs and turn based combat this is a delight and pleasure to play.

[h3]Story:[/h3]
You're thrust into this world with a bang, putting your character and potential companions in a shared predicament which sets the stage of the whole adventure. The entry to this story is masterful and makes for very interesting storytelling both with the overarching grand plot as well as the small side encounters you'll find along the way.

Being thrust into the world of Faerûn might be daunting with years of lore behind it, but there's plenty of books and scrolls scattered in the world where you can read up on lore that will help you understand the setting better, but it's not required. Larian managed to keep the story quite easily understandable and the extra knowledge about lore will only enhance your experience rather than take away if you don't have it.

[h3]Gameplay:[/h3]
It's going to be hard for me to sell you the gameplay if you're not interested in turn-based gameplay as I am a very big fan of it myself, and that's just my taste. But I have a lot of friends who don't play turn-based games who have loved this game. As it's turn-based your skill with navigating the controls won't matter too much, but rather your knowledge of the game and system. And I've seen many friends who don't play many games pick this monster of a game up and really enjoy it as they can take their time without stress.

It's all based on the Dungeons & Dragons 5th edition ruleset, which has its drawbacks in certain cases. For example, there's always a chance your hit will miss, which could be completely negated in their previous title Divinity Original Sin 2. But also Larian Studios have managed to tweak the ruleset to fit the video game platform really well, and most changes are definitely for the better. One major point here that differs from the tabletop RPG is the emphasis on gear and looting, and usually the gearpieces will help against the drawbacks of the system.

[h3]Music and Ambience:[/h3]
Borislav Slavov wrote a masterpiece of a soundtrack which sets the stage of every scene. The landscapes and ambient sound and music push the feel of every scene, all from the lush forest to a bustling city. I wholeheartedly recommend you don't look up some of the music of the game until you've played it, many songs contain spoilers either in titles or in the song itself. But I won't blame you if you can't resist, I definitely listened to the whole soundtrack whenever I wasn't playing the game.

[h3]Performance[/h3]
It's clear from most who've played the game that the performance goes down throughout the three acts. Act 1 is great and has very few bugs and glitches, but those increase as you play the game. I was lucky enough and haven't encountered too many or breaking bugs during my time of playing.

Although much of the criticism it's gotten for its poor late game performance has been changed, they've even added a lot to the epilogue of the game to flesh out the stories of all characters. If there's a time to play it it's definitely way more stable now than it was on release.

Overall it's in great shape and I wouldn't tell anyone to not get this game because of the performance as of right now.

[h3]Summary:[/h3]
If you still haven't picked this game up I highly recommend it to anyone interested in an epic story, want amazing character progression both mechanic and storywise or just want to cause chaos in a fantasy world. The developers deserve full price and I'd encourage you to support them. A fully finished game with tons of content and no microtransactions, we should reward that behaviour as gamers.

One point on the length of the game, I've heard many people say "it's a 100h game, that's way too long for me", and although yes it's very long I think it's an unfair argument. I'd compare this to a great TV or book series rather than a movie. For example, it's supposed to take its time and build up. And you're put on different crescendos and slow points as the game is structured in different acts that have their own climaxes. And if you need to take a longer break, the journal system is great to write out exactly what has happened and what your goals are, use it!

Lastly I'd like to give a few pointers for anyone picking this up, the obvious is don't look up anything beforehand and experience the game for yourself. There is no "wrong" way to do things, and even though it might make some things harder, always remember you can inspect any enemy to see their abilities and weaknesses.

Secondly don't play for the first run with friends, if you must then maximum 2 people. You'll lose a lot of story from the companions by not being able to bring them along with the story with a full group of 4 player co-op.

Hope you have fun with this amazing game.

157952405.review:
This is definitely my GOTY. One of the best CRPGs of all time. (TIP - Rest a lot or you'll miss a lot of additional dialogue with your companions)

If you like RPGs, tactics, huge adventures and bears, the game is a must-buy. It's not a question. The only real question is: Are you into turn-based combat, tough choices, intrigues, ready to spend at least 100 hours+ into the game?

GAMEPLAY

It's an isometric RPG, very well executed. Combat is turn based, very similiar to Divinity Original Sin. You can exploit almost any fight as much as you want, throw hundreds of barrels upon your enemies just before setting them on fire. It's as bad as great in my opinion. I've talked to multiple bosses just to reload my save, setup a perfect ambush and just obliterate them without any dialogue. Seems weird. Boss too tough? Surround him with explosive barrels before a fight and blow his ass off,

Larian did something great combining classical RPGs and their own style. You have your ordinary RPG: classes, abilities, XP, lockpicking, multiclasses. Then you have a simulated world that you can interact with in creative way. Can't pick a chest? Just take it away to open in camp or just smash the lock instead of lockpicking it. 

EXPLORATION

I got bored of generic RPG games, which didn't reward a player for being curious. Be curious here. Go here, there and there and you'll be rewarded. Either be it with an item or even a quest. It definitely delivers the exploration aspect. It is dense and even emptier areas are packed with surprises. Characters, chests, secrets, stories, scrolls, books (READ THEM, they give lots of information and lore).

STORY

It's mostly great, but it kinda doesn't deliver at the end aswell. You've got a lot of choices to make, paths to decide, yet they get narrower the more the story progresses. It's hit and miss. Don't get me wrong, the acting, characters and story is still phenomenal, just uneven in my opinion.
Some core characters miss a lot of opportunity to be even deeper, it just ends so quick with either black or white. The deeper we go, the shallower waters we encounter.

Companions are on a completely different level. You've got so many unique, talented, charismatic characters in this game, it blows my mind. To be fair their stories got me more engaged than the main story. Even though some of them left me immediately after some of my choices, I'm still eager to let another playthrough a go, just to see their stories and reactions.

SOUNDTRACK

Cannot to mention the phenomenal OST. It's great at least said. Some songs are just... another level. You don't or won't forget them, flashbacks from the fights and exploration will comeback. Borislav Slavov did climb up to his top! Even after beating the game, I still keep coming back to those great memories.

Game's totally worth full price.

Okay, I'll be real with you:

I love this game.
There are a lot of minor inconveniences throughout the game, so you need to put in some effort to enjoy certain parts.
This game is a sandbox, especially with the story, so some story elements may feel clunky.
Stealth and moving through the battlefield feel just wrong most of the time.
Pickpocketing and other activities have no enjoyable gameplay around them except save scumming.
I've played 500 hours of accumulated Larian Studio games, and these problems usually occur. So, I don't expect them to be solved.
This game is amazing. I don't remember really caring for the dialogs and story since Disco Elysium. To be honest, every game tries to make lovable characters, but Baldur's Gate made a case for study.
The amount of content this game has is absurd; you cannot possibly explore all of it in one playthrough at all.
For someone who played Divinity: Original Sin 2, this game's battles are on another level. Builds and strategies are deeper than DND 5e because of the large array of specific items.
Cosmetically, it's hecking impressive. Not at the level of graphics paragon, but the art design and graphics really complement each other near perfectly. Even with limited character creation tools, it's mostly inclusive.
Roleplaying is fully possible, and this luxury is actually very rare at this age.
Modding is very easy and accessible; it's improving every day even more.

156928093.review:
A love letter to the Forgotten Realms

Where do I even begin? Baldur's Gate 3 isn't just a game, it's a portal back to that magical era of sprawling Forgotten Realms adventures, reinvigorated with modern brilliance. Larian Studios hasn't simply captured the spirit of the Baldur's Gate legacy, they've infused it with their own brand of narrative audacity and tactical complexity, crafting an RPG experience that feels both nostalgic and revolutionary.

Story woven with silk and shadow: Prepare to be enthralled by a tale that writhes and twists like a mindflayer tentacle. Your choices ripple through the narrative, leaving a trail of butterfly wings – or dragonfire, depending on your penchant for mischief. Every character pulsates with life and complexity. Their interwoven stories dance around yours, creating a tapestry rich in emotional resonance and moral quandaries.

Combat: The turn-based battles are a masterclass in strategic depth. Every spell cast, every swing of the blade feels weighty and consequential. Positioning is everything, terrain becomes your playground, and creative spell combinations unleash symphonies of destruction. I've spent hours lost in tactical ecstasy, relishing the thrill of a perfectly executed ambush or the gut-punching defeat that forces me to rethink my entire approach.

A feast for the senses: From the sun-drenched meadows of the Druid Grove to the claustrophobic depths of the Underdark, every inch of this world hums with visual splendor. Environments are meticulously crafted, brimming with detail and personality. The voice acting is superb, each character delivering their lines with a passion that pulls you deeper into the narrative. And the soundtrack? Oh, the soundtrack! Every note is an echo of adventure, a melody that fuels your spirit as you face down the perils of Faerun.

Is it flawless? No. There is the occasional bug or stutter. But these are easily forgiven in the face of the magnificent whole.

Baldur's Gate 3 isn't just a game, it's a homecoming. It's a return to a world we cherish. It's a reminder of why we fell in love with RPGs in the first place. If you're seeking an adventure that will grip your soul, ignite your imagination, and leave you yearning for more, look no further. This is Baldur's Gate 3, and it's an absolute masterpiece.

10/10 – An instant classic, hands down. Just try to pry yourself away from Faerun, I dare you.

P.S. Don't forget to pet the dog. You won't regret it.

156772773.review:
An Epic Journey through the Forgotten Realms: Baldur's Gate 3 Review

Baldur's Gate 3, the highly anticipated RPG developed by Larian Studios, takes players on a thrilling adventure through the iconic Forgotten Realms. As someone who has delved into the game extensively, with 70 hours on Steam and an impressive 200 hours on PS5, it's safe to say that Baldur's Gate 3 offers an expansive and immersive experience that captivates players from start to finish.

Graphics and Visuals: 4.5/5

Baldur's Gate 3 boasts stunning visuals that bring the Forgotten Realms to life with meticulous attention to detail. The character designs are diverse and expressive, and the environments are richly detailed. However, occasional glitches and visual bugs can detract from the overall experience, but these issues are relatively minor and do not significantly impact the game's enjoyment.

Gameplay: 4.8/5

The gameplay in Baldur's Gate 3 is a masterclass in tactical RPG design. The turn-based combat system is both strategic and engaging, providing players with a plethora of options to approach encounters. The inclusion of verticality in combat adds an extra layer of complexity, making each battle feel dynamic and unpredictable. The branching narrative and robust dialogue system allow for meaningful choices, ensuring that each playthrough offers a unique experience. The game excels in providing a sense of agency, making players feel truly immersed in the choices that shape the story.

Story and Worldbuilding: 4.7/5

Baldur's Gate 3 successfully captures the essence of the Dungeons & Dragons universe, presenting a rich narrative that unfolds in a vast and detailed world. The lore is deep and engaging, with well-written characters that contribute to the overall immersion. The unfolding story is filled with twists and turns, keeping players on the edge of their seats and eager to discover the next chapter of their character's journey. The game excels in balancing serious themes with moments of humor, creating a well-rounded and enjoyable narrative experience.

Performance: 4/5 (Steam) | 4.5/5 (PS5)

On Steam, the game generally performs well, with smooth framerates and minimal loading times on a capable system. However, occasional crashes and bugs can disrupt the experience, but frequent updates from the developers show a commitment to addressing these issues promptly. On the PS5, the performance is even more polished, with smoother transitions and improved stability, showcasing the game's optimization for the platform.

Overall: 4.7/5

Baldur's Gate 3 is a triumph in the realm of RPGs, offering a compelling narrative, strategic gameplay, and a visually stunning world to explore. The occasional technical hiccups are overshadowed by the game's overall excellence, making it a must-play for fans of the genre and newcomers alike. Whether you're exploring the Forgotten Realms on PC or diving into the adventure on the innovative Steam Deck, Baldur's Gate 3 stands as a shining example of Larian Studios' dedication to delivering a memorable and captivating gaming experience.

156650681.review:
At the time of writing this, I have nearly 800 hours in this game. Perhaps that speaks for itself. But if I had to give it a few more words: 

BG3 has quickly become one of my favorite games of all time. It is not without flaws. Bugs still populate Faerun in great numbers, and the freedom to solve problems in a myriad of ways means there are occasional moments where the logic of the game strains under the pressure of your creative choices. But the latter is also why I love the game so much; it feels like a place where I can make it my own, and take part in crafting the story of my character. 

My biggest gripes after several playthroughs: 
- The game does not tell you that resting is a necessary way of progressing storylines and character arcs. Nearly every person I know that has played the game has mentioned that they missed out on a massive number of things because of this. The best fix would be a simple notification whenever a new camp scene becomes available. I hope Larian might add this by default, although modders have also fixed this by now. 
- The pacing of the game feels off, story-wise. Without spoilers, the urgency created by the end of Act 2 makes the entry into Act 3 feel as though there is time pressure to reach the endgame; other than a few small differences in the outcome of some side quests, there is no actual consequence to taking your time in Act 3. It also feels odd to be doing so many side quests in Act 3 when you have world-ending stakes hanging over you, but this complaint is only a small one, as I love how [i]big[/i] the world feels, and the breadth of content is part of that. 

My biggest praises:
- The characters, with very few exceptions, are written with emotional depth and complexity. I am constantly impressed by the writing of this game, in little corner of the world. I have been brought to tears, felt sadness and heartbreak, laughed at the absurdity, and asked to think deeply about conceptual topics. While not every one of the companion characters completely vibed with me, I can appreciate that they are all written in a way that makes them feel rooted in the world, with their own opinions and feelings and experiences. If you are patient as a player, and give them time to develop, they all have storylines that are rewarding and often incredibly moving. 
- The gameplay is endlessly entertaining, because you are given the freedom to re-spec your (and your companions') build whenever you wish. As someone who plays a fair bit of 5e, the game also feels like the best video game port that the ttrpg could hope for. 
- Larian has proven they are dedicated to supporting and polishing the game post-release. The addition of the magic mirror, and later the new epilogue scene, was incredibly welcome. This game was created with love and care, and it shows. 

For my final review:
11/10, you can pet the dog and owlbear cub at the same time <3

156506830.review:
[h3][b]184 hours in 15 days. I've never reached an amount of hours this high on a game within such a short timeframe.[/b][/h3]


The graphics are breathtaking.
The overall movement works well, the combat is surprisingly well-made even if you don't favour turn-based system.
The story goes deep, and you go there with it - it's hard to get back up after a couple of in-game hours.
The characters are.. written. Exquisitely written and flawlessly executed in the game, indeed. They have their own personality, their own archs, and they have you as means of their salvation or doom. You rise and fall with them, you lead them towards the favorable ending, or a catastrophe. Or you just kill them straight away. Yes, you can do that too.
YOU form this world, it's YOU who decides what happens next and it is YOU who faces the consequences of those decisions.

What Larian created is an immersive world full of encounters, full of problems with some requiring a solution, and full of small decisions which might, or might not matter in the long run. It's exactly what I would've expected from a world that is supposed to feel [i]actually alive[/i]. The amount of things you can do AND HOW you can get to do them in this game is crazy. 

Want to play as a generally good guy? Go for it!
Want to be aligned more towards the neutral side of things? Boring, but you can!
Want to be an absolute menace to everyone, including your peers? Godspeed, and you can find companions who think alike!
Want to ruin absolutely everything you touch, every relationship you make, and every encounter you might've positively solved, right afterwards? I was shocked that you can do even that.

The best thing about this game is that it allows you to do EVERYTHING. Yes, you can use a child's corpse as an improvised weapon. Yes, it's questionable, but you can do it - how you get it in the first place is best kept under the lid. Yes, you can wipe out an entire village and the world won't break; instead it will actually react to your actions.

This game deserves all the praise it got. It offers an amazing experience with huge replayability, guaranteeing hundreds of hours spent in the world either alone or with friends via co-op - all that and you'll [b]most likely[/b] still find things you haven't encountered in the last 150 hours, for example.

[u][b]Strongly recommended to buy for a full price - they deserve it after delivering a game that has set a great example for other studios to follow.[/b][/u]

156295331.review:
From the moment Baldur's Gate 3 begins, you know you're in for something special. This game is more than a mere sequel; it's a triumph in video game storytelling, a breakthrough in RPG mechanics (probably more than 100 ways of just doing the Goblin Camp), and a dazzling spectacle of fantasy world-building.

The first thing that strikes you about Baldur's Gate 3 is its stunningly detailed world. Every environment is a work of art, teeming with hand-crafted details and intricate lore. Whether you're exploring the Underdark or the city itself, the game's world is so immersive that you can't help but feel part of its history and future.

Character customization and development are where Baldur's Gate 3 really shines. The range of races, classes, and backgrounds available allows for countless unique character builds. Your party members are not just fighters; they are characters with their own stories, beliefs, and personalities, making every interaction meaningful.

Technically, the game is a marvel. The graphics are breathtaking for a crpg, the voice acting is top-notch, and the soundtrack is both haunting and beautiful. The attention to detail in every aspect of the game's design and execution is evident.

There are definitely some bugs in Act 3 but Larian has done an excellent job patching them. I also highly recommend Honor Mode once you learn the game, with the golden dice being an excellent prize.

Absolutely recommend it. May very well be my new favorite game of all time.

156256628.review:
I very rarely write reviews for games, but here we go.

I always figured I'd never experience the same 'feeling' playing a cRPG as I did when playing Dragon Age: Origins on release. Mostly because I figured nostalgia probably played a huge part in my fondness for the game.

However, I felt the same sense of giddy excitement I felt then while playing BG3. I was, once again, like a kid experiencing their first big Triple A title. Baldur's Gate 3 is truly a gem of a game and is crafted by a team that is passionate about not only weaving a compelling narrative with characters that could truly be real people but also about designing game play that  keeps surprising the player after of hundreds of hours.

BG3 allows the player an insane amount of agency in approaching conversations, fights, big arc defining moments, and sometimes you can mess up so badly you contemplate reloading because you're dumbfounded at just how terribly something turned out.

The game is massive and filled to the brim with content! Even after, what I thought was, two incredibly detailed play throughs, I still found things I'd never run across before in subsequent games. And that's just playing the Dark Urge Origin & the default Tav. BUT THEN, you can play as companion Origin characters and see whole new sets of dialogue and scenarios you'd never experience with the default character. 

While no game is 100% perfect, BG3 comes pretty damn close, in my opinion. From narrative, to combat, to class design, to  the voice acting, it hits every note near perfect. I could probably wax on forever about the talent of the entire VA cast, but I won't, beyond saying everyone gave their all for these characters.

So BRAV-freaking-O, Larian, for making BG3 my new standard for RPGs. I have a feeling nothing will come even close for a long, long time.

PS: No game is for everyone, and if its not your cup of tea, that's okay. :)

156151423.review:
Spiderman be damned, this game is pretty damn good.

To preface this review, I spent the first three months of release saying that this game was going to be trash.  I came from early access and stopped playing somewhere around patch 3 or 4 of early access. I felt that the game was way too buggy and had next to no content.  I knew a lot more was going to come out in the future, but I was a skeptic.  At the time, I was enjoying Divinity 2 and felt that this game was lacking in freedom during combat.  Now, I have completed the story twice, and am working on an honour mode completion.  I believe that the game was made with true care and love and that the game play is both immersive and fantastic.

Everyone who worked on this game must have had a blast, since every aspect of this game seems to have been made with love and with player creativity in mind.  Like the tabletop game it is based off of (D&D), the game allows for many creative solutions to each problem.  Having trouble with a boss? Try shoving it off the edge for a quick win.  While this tactic loses on grabbing that sweet loot, it is one of the many tactics that can be used to accomplish your goals.  In one part of Act I, there is a particular goblin, whose interactions with you change based on your race and build.  You also can choose to deal with this npc in various other ways.  This extends to every aspect of this game, and it never feels like the game forces you to do something a specific way.

Moreover, your choices matter.  Killing an npc early on will have real consequences down the line, and finishing a quest line may reward you with unique endings or access to better loot all the way in Act 3.  This game is far from the TellTale classic, "Astarion will remember this." and actually makes you feel like you can have an impact on this world.  The voice acting, dialogue, and animations all lend themselves to making the characters feel real and relatable.  You want to help the people in this world, and playing the villain always feels terrible.

Finally, combat in this game is quite amazing.  At first, it feels like a slug fest, where no one really does too much to each other, and many rounds are spent dashing and chasing each other down.  As the game progresses, you learn how to use this combat system to your advantage.  You learn what builds are really strong when an enemy pummels your entire party, and what builds are weak when your rogue druid ranger multi-class build can't make anything happen (I am determined to run this in 5e).  I will say, that you will have an advantage if you have played D&D before, as the system used in this game is quite similar, maybe even easier for PCs.

Overall, although my expectations were abysmally low, I was surprised with how much I enjoyed this game.  I am sure I will be playing this game for years, and I am also sure that I have only scratched the surface.
