156095565.review:
Wanted to finish the game before reviewing. Played over the course of the last month, and hard to think of many other games that brought up so many emotions since a long time. This is such an incredible way to tell a story of this scale. 

I want to review all 3 Acts, as there seems to be a lot of opinions about how they differentiate. But before that, I will give one 'fair warning', and probably my only negative point:


COMBAT SYSTEM
The D&D turn based strategy combat system is really not for everyone. I personally love it, but even then, it's akward to play on a controller (yes, I didn't want to sit at my desk playing this, much happier playing it on my couch :D). The first 10 hours of the game were challenging to get a grasp of all the mechanics and how to optimize my battles. It wasn't just the combat itself, but the way your actions and spells organize themselves automatically without making much sense. It become messy quickly when you have a class with lot of abilities, and you regularly need to re-organise your ability slots. I don't understand why the game wouldn't automatically separate ability radials in categories 'Physical Dmg, Magical Dmg, Support Abilities' as default.

Anyway, it was only after 5-10 hours that I eventually looked for a tutorial online for optimizing your play through with controller, and that eventually changed completely how I enjoyed the game in a very positive way. 


STORY
The strength of this game for me, is just the depth of storytelling. It is brilliant, outstanding and I think there are enough reviews out there for me not to spend time on it. So here is how I personally experienced each acts. Most of it is SPOILER FREE, and has spoiler warnings.


ACT I: 
The pure joy of discovering BG3's lore right there. I couldn't find any flaws in this act besides the lack of tutorials. I purposely chose to play this Act without exploring all the areas, because the way the encounters guided me through the story felt so organic that I didn't feel I was missing anything really, and that if I played again, I'll experience something new. For example, I played this Act without encountering Astarion. No regrets whatsoever. I got to build a party with Shadowheart/Karlach/Wyll - and bring some other companions in my camps along the way. What a pure joy this act was.

There was a simplicity to it that I loved, Quests felt all worthy of being considered, and choices felt very organic and impactful! I also picked up and read every lore book I could find. It is just such an amazing adventure start for loremongers, and sets so many little things in motions for you to experience later in the game!


ACT II:
Probably my favorite story arch of the game. Without spoiling, Shadowheart has such a great narrative - and this act is full of great moments for her. But overall, the tragedies and darkness of this act are so poignant, the combats are meaningful, and the results of ending it felt really 'worth it' as far as story goes.

However, this is where I started getting my first taste of narrative inconsistencies. Nothing crazy, but some NPC interactions made little sense, and triggering certain quests before talking to a character about it, felt kind of inorganic. I also felt a lack of 'choices' at times. Nothing major though.

SPOILER: Lifting the Shadow curse felt inorganic. I couldn't find the right interaction to trigger in order to complete it - and yet, it's reminded so much by NPCs that it felt soooo important not to ignore, and had to cheat this one before leaving ACT II. Only quest I looked for solution online.


Finally, I would love for the game to close access to areas of ACT I as soon as you enter ACT II. I didn't explore all of ACT I areas, and ended up exploring the mountain pass during ACT II in a way which made not much sense at this point of the story. Kind of ruined the immersion for me.


ACT III: 
A controversial act when checking reviews - but to me, such an EPIC one. The issue with this act in my opinion is that there is too much to do. Act I had such an organic storytelling, and you feel Act 3 tried to achieve the same but x10, which can give at time a lot of inconsistencies and confusion.

Personally, it was more the first part of act III which annoyed me. It had really distracting and unnecessary quest lines which made me spend so much time in Rivington trying to find meaning to it all, meaning which was not there at all, but actually beyond the bridge which was blocked. 

Only when I passed the bridge did I feel a sense of wonder again, away from helping delivery pigeons and looking for clown body parts... But never did an NPC tell me that I should go there. They mention various areas of Baldurs Gate, but don't tell you in which direction to go.

And so, I felt lost in my first 10 hours of ACT III, exploring right and left corners looking for things which felt important but weren't. Guards wouldn't let me pass the bridge without arresting me even when Disguised. Just took it as an incentive to explore more, and while there are some nice stuff to discover, they really don't all feel necessary. Eventually just decided to turn invisible only to discover that passed them is where Act III really starts to unfold.

Wyrming Crossing is really what I hoped Rivington would be. That's where you set the pieces for the overall Baldurs Gate Arch. And it's really good. Why make me waste so much time in Rivington?


The biggest area of ACT III is truly a town of Epic proportion. Lot of great story moments in my opinion, and enough choices that build up on how you want to end the game. In many moments, I truly thought twice about what I wanted to do exactly. However, again, some useless side quests felt distracting at some point, keeping me away from what truly mattered.

SPOILER: I don't understand why with a game this big, you still have to prompt a quest to clear rats in a basement, from a guy you just told was going to be assassinated. Do I look like an exterminator really? With all that bloodied gear I wear? Can't you give me another meaningful reason to go the the basement?


Overall, there are quite a few dialogue inconsistencies depending on which order you decide to explore ACT III. These inconsistencies, bring lack of depth in some choices, creating unfortunately a need to 'save scum' the game before any important interaction, and the reason is simply because some choices felt kind of unclear. And they can have such an impact on the story.

But, it's something you have to learn to live with. The act III is so rich in side quests that make the outcome of saving Baldurs Gate really worth it. Overall a really great experience, but I would love to 'trim some of the fat' when it comes to unnecessary interactions that may seem important, but really aren't.

[b]GOTY'23[/b]
Isn't everything already posted?

I've never had cake like this before, you know? Well, when cake is soaked in all that magic and how do you even eat it? Haha. ✨
But this cake is definitely inimitable and unique. You don't notice time passing and you realize it's the middle of the night and you're still eating that damn dragon in Wyrmway. So where do I start?

I'll start with the enchanting voice of [b]Amelia Tyler[/b], without whom I just can't imagine BG3. And that's probably what the crust of this cake is soaked in. It is the very first 'character' of the game that you meet and that stays with you till the very end regardless of your fate. The voice... 💜

All, absolutely all of the characters are so well-developed and charismatic that they seem real. It's the cream that binds each of the layers of the acts together. After all, your companions become a real family. I would especially like to recognize the work of actors [b]Neil Newbon[/b] (Astarion) and [b]Devora Wilde[/b] (Lae'zel). Their work was done just grandiose and it was their voice work that gave the characters incredible charisma.

What really amazes me is that adventure awaits the player LITERALLY at every turn! Seriously, you can turn a corner or walk into a small store and you're already involved in another adventure! Delicious! Or... Very tasty mhahaha! 

I would also point out the deep elaboration of the world and game mechanics, as well as the developers' loyalty to the gaming community.
You can't handle the boss? Here are some options and the boss is overthrown!
Want to change the appearance or class of the character? Easy, you can even change the gender if you want to. That's what's really missing in most games. 🌧

The music is also a big, shall we say, decoration to this 'cake'. 🎻
After all, the music is really beautiful. My favorite part is, of course. the battle with Raphael. It was really good kicking his ass while he sang about how sick of me he was. 😂😇

And my character is the heart of this confection. My [b]Cassiopeia[/b] the tiefling who managed to save the world and all her friends! I'm happy with my finale, but I said goodbye with sadness in my heart. 🖤💜

[b]This is the most delicious cake I've had in 2023 (and a little bit in 2024)![/b] 🥂⚡️✨

158049431.review:
A late-medieval fantasy adventure with science fiction undertones where the story begins with you and two women having alien symbiotes implanted in your brains before escaping from an alien skycruiser under fire from dragons mounted by other aliens. You proceed to find three guys and another woman with the same symbiote problem as yourself and begin looking for a solution to that problem. That's all I'm revealing of the story just so you know what to expect initially, because everything else is best experienced blindly. Having beaten the game once, I can't think of an uninteresting story component anywhere. This game is masterfully written.

Gameplay is top-down, point-and-click, turn-based tactical role-playing. The outcome of combat actions, object interactions and certain dialogue choices are determined by the game rolling 20-sided dice - the number the dice need to match or beat is higher the harder the action is, and the skill being tested is added to whichever number you get. If this kind of system sounds familiar, you've either played tactical role-playing games before, or you've played Dungeons and Dragons, which very likely is an inspiration to whichever tactical RPG's you've played. The story, in fact, takes place in the DnD universe. Does this mean that you need to be a DnD player to enjoy BG3? No. 

The user interface is generally easy, although the inventory window takes some time to learn properly. Camera controls allow you to either move the view around freely (except not upwards or downwards) or keep the camera centered on the character you're controlling at the moment.

The graphics are brilliant. More importantly, they're well optimized - I'm running the game on a PC that just about meets the minimum requirements, and getting a smooth and pretty experience on graphics settings above the minimum. This game has Bethesda seething.

The soundtrack is a great mix of intense orchestral combat music and meditative fantasy ambience. Combined with atmospheric and charismatic narration and brilliant voice acting - one of the actors pulled home 2023's voice acting award at the Game Awards - resulting in peak immersion.

My last point is one we rarely get reasons to talk about in this age of launch-day DLC's, lootboxes, subscriptions and pay-to-win schemes. This game has an *insane* lot and depth of *content*, and a rarely seen degree of replayability. You're finally getting what you pay for.

In conclusion, this game pulling home 6 wins on the 2023 Game Awards wasn't the result of someone getting blown. This is the first game in the past 10 years priced at 60 euros to actually be worth 60 euros.

There's so much praise that's already been said. So I will add a few things that I haven't seen mentioned.

I really love how this can almost feel like two different types of game. Sometimes I play with mouse and keyboard, zoom all the way out, and enable edge panning, clicking where I'd like my party to go. It can feel like Baldur's Gate 1 and 2 and other CRPGs. Then sometimes I play with a controller and zoom all the way in. Directly controlling my main character's movement and swapping to the radial menus on the fly makes it feel like a third person action game while exploring.

I also love the fact I can split my party up and have other members go to other locations, explore, do quests, while my main character is off somewhere else. It makes splitting up the party actually feel like a dynamic feature instead of only being a means to scout ahead a little bit.

I feel like anything I think of that I wish I could do in this game, I discover I can actually do.

Also it runs on Geforce Now, so I can play it on literally anything with an internet connection.

Baldur's Gate 3 is a rare gem in today’s gaming that set a very high bar not only for RPG's, but games in general.

A beautiful world that feels alive, compelling narrative, masterfully written and voiced characters, endless amounts of tools and ways (limited only by your imagination and creativity) to tackle any situation - are the key aspects of this masterpiece that keep you coming for more.

The game has great replay value, as there are choices to be made every step of the way, which influence how the plot evolves and encounters turn out. Regardless of whether you're going for a single playthrough or multiple - there's content for hundreds of hours.

I have to warn new players to the genre though - the game is incredibly complex, which can be very daunting at first.

Having no previous experience with DnD, I can say that this game doesn’t hold your hand at all and has a very steep learning curve to the point where I nearly dropped the game all together less than 10 hours in.

I rate this game a VERY solid 9/10. 100% recommend you buy this if you do not already own it, and just 1/3 of the game itself is worth full price. And trust me, this is one of those games you want to take your time with. Really envelop yourself in its world, or you're doing yourself and the game a great disservice. YOUR CHOICES MATTER, this is not a pseudo butterfly effect, nor illusion of choice. Your actions have SEVERE consequences even towards the end of the game where you least expect.

If somehow you are someone who is yet to acquire this game; I implore you to stop considering and just make the purchase. I personally went in doubting I was going to enjoy it, mostly influenced by some friends to give it a shot- and boy am I glad I kept going with it. 

Baldurs Gate 3, in a vacuum is an incredible roleplaying adventure with heavy DnD influence. The voice cast, the art team, hell the programmers all did such an incredible job giving the game, its characters, and the world such life and personality. 

I will make mention of course, that there will be bugs. There may be run-ending bugs. This is something you just have to expect unfortunately with a project with such a large scope. Does it suck knowing you could lose 50+ hours of your time because of a stupid coding conflict? Of course. But all that means is you have to play through the amazing, fleshed out beginning part of the game again... what a terrible fate! 
As of writing this, I have 156 hours in the game, and I have yet to complete a single run- because of the sheer amount of replayability each act has (of which there are 3) and some modding issues I ran into of my own design, nothing because of the game itself. 

If there were ever a dev team or corporation worthy of shilling 60 dollars to for a game, its Larian Studios. Baldur's Gate 3 is more than just a game. It's more than the sum of its parts. On the surface, yes, it's a fantastic, story-driven epic adventure with a plethora of memorable characters. There's so many ways to play, so many ways to tackle encounters. But beneath that game itself are developers who are passionate. It's a beautiful work of art, and it's also a statement. The statement that games can be made without micro-transactions. Games can be made without forcing players to be online to play. In an industry plagued by giant corporations and appeasing the ever-hungry stakeholders, Baldur's Gate 3 is a breath of fresh air.

If there ever was a game that deserved a perfect 10/10, Baldur's Gate 3 would be it.

"It’s like in the great stories, Mr. Frodo. The ones that really mattered. Full of darkness and danger they were. And sometimes you didn’t want to know the end. Because how could the end be happy. How could the world go back to the way it was when so much bad had happened.

But in the end, it’s only a passing thing, this shadow. Even darkness must pass. A new day will come. And when the sun shines it will shine out the clearer. Those were the stories that stayed with you. That meant something. Even if you were too small to understand why. But I think, Mr. Frodo, I do understand. I know now. Folk in those stories had lots of chances of turning back only they didn’t. Because they were holding on to something....

That there’s some good in this world, Mr. Frodo. And it’s worth fighting for."

156547324.review:
"Baldur's Gate 3" is a captivating adventure that engages players on both a personal and epic level. The game's depth in character development and motivations is so profound that each character leaves a lasting impression. Their humanity and realistic struggles in aspirations and problems are especially striking​​.

The game stands out for its graphics and optimization, offering players the ability to make significant choices that affect the future narrative. It enriches gameplay with a variety of mechanics, classes, and races, allowing players to create their dream squad. The game includes options for choosing subclasses, changing classes, and reallocating characteristics, adding flexibility and the opportunity to experiment with different play styles​​.

With a detailed character editor, players can spend hours fine-tuning their ideal character, as well as choose from ready-made heroes with unique stories and personal narrative arcs. The game also offers unique development paths for characters like The Dark Temptation, whose story includes brutal dialogue options and internal conflicts​​.

A key aspect of "Baldur's Gate 3" is the freedom of choice. The game allows players to decide how they want to interact with the world and its inhabitants, offering multiple approaches to solving tasks and conflicts. Players can choose which battles to fight, which dialogues to engage in, and which decisions to make, making each playthrough a unique and personal experience​​.

Overall, "Baldur's Gate 3" is a meticulously thought-out, expansive, and impressively executed role-playing adventure that offers a deep and interactive gaming experience, satisfying both genre enthusiasts and newcomers.

156250252.review:
Baldur's Gate III has impacted me more than any game to date has. The love that the creators, developers, actors, directors, authors, et al. put in is deep and it is palpable. Such an intricate RPG has given me the unique experience of learning more about myself and who I am. I am grateful for that.

You will experience all manner of emotion playing this game, the story and the world suck you in effortlessly. The sheer number of things you can do would seem overwhelming if it weren't for their very, very clever placement of hidden stories, areas, and quests. I have still not found everything after multiple campaigns and over 300 hours of playing. There is a lot that is easy to overlook, and that makes it all the more satisfying when you do discover something or figure it out.

This was my first time properly playing a turn-based RPG, at first I was unsure but as I played more it's become almost an addictive form of chess! Each battle differs significantly enough that I have to think carefully and consider my strategy. It is even fun to go back and replay battles immediately just to see if you could have done something more efficiently. In most games, after defeating a difficult boss or battle, I have no desire to immediately replay it.

The life that the authors and actors gave these characters is unlike anything I have ever seen. They are complex, full, well-rounded people who are not simply morally black or white (or even just simply on a scale) -- everyone has their own idiosyncrasies and unique views of the world, just like real people. And they can change, in big ways and in subtle ways. Your influence over the world and its characters has profound impact.

This is a piece of art that I am fortunate to be able to enjoy for many more years to come! 10/10

157613269.review: In an age where AAA developers mindlessly obsess over scale and attempt to appease the lowest common denominator, Larian Studios, however, focus on depth and artistry. BG3 does not have 1000+ planets nor miles of empty void to traverse through just to reach the quest marker. Instead, it has a concise but beautifully crafted world brimming with fun that the player can stumble upon with every single step they take. BG3 does not railroad the player into engaging with the game in the exact way that the devs envisioned. Instead, it simply offers the player some necessary context and leaves them to adventure however they see fit. BG3 does not force the player to journey with a bunch of brainless sycophants that exist solely to fulfill the player's power fantasy. Instead, it stars a cast of wonderfully written and voice-acted companions as well as other characters with actual personality and volition. I am more than grateful that a game such as Baldur's Gate 3 can be conceived in the year 2023 and enjoy the commercial success and critical acclaim that it deserved, and I am beyond excited to see whatever Larian's vision proceeds to bring.

156583630.review:
Ugh, as someone who to this day religiously plays [i]Baldur's Gate 1[/i] and [I]2[/i], thinking about Larian's attempt at the much, much hoped-for [i]Baldur's Gate 3[/i] makes me upset. This game quite literally has all the pitfalls of their [i]Divinity[/i] games (limp, bargain-bin main plot, crammed and claustrophobic level design, trigger-happy AI, force-dialogues, pandering, etc.) and it's befuddling that so many are inclined to write these flaws off. Is [i]BG3[/i] a decent game? Sure, it's fun to play. Is [i]BG3[/i] a 96% Metacritic game? No.

Now, I ain't gonna pass judgment because I prefer the frenzied, life-or-death fights that the RtwP classics had bestowed upon us – that subject was exhausted years ago – but rather I'll try to look at this game as objectively as possible – while also taking into account that much better RPGs like [i]Disco Elysium[/i] exist.

So here's my review after 200+ hours (1 EA playthrough, 1 Tav playthrough, 1 Durge playthrough):

[h1][b]PROS:[/b][/h1]
[list]
[*] The combat system is solid and the boss fights are really fun (shout-out goes to my boy Raphael and the House of Grief for catching me with my pants down). The final fight, though, is the exception (see below). 
[*] Huge scope, high production value, and lots of content with well-animated cutscenes. Voice-acting for your companions is top-notch too, in particular Astarion and Karlach. The side characters' voice-acting is a bit more of a mixed bag (see below).
[/list]

[h1][b]CONS:[/b][/h1]
[b]FLAWS[/b]
[list]
[*] The writing is... not engaging. The main plot is so trite and predictable that you'll be groaning out loud at all the plot holes and straight-out previous [i]Baldur's Gate[/i] games/Forgotten Realms lore retcons. It's filled to the brim with contrived coincidences, incomprehensible motivations, a cliché sticky MacGuffin, an inscrutable force that makes you its Chosen One, and genre blind cretins for enemies – by the Nine Hells, just *search* Tav and the party and you'll find that stupid artifact! – and as a result, the pacing feels like “Look at this! Now look at that! Hehe, there's a HAT!” Sure, the game tries to excuse all of the above by stating that [spoiler]the Netherbrain had planned everything from the start[/spoiler], but this lame quote-unquote 'twist' comes in the last ten minutes of the game. And the fact [spoiler]the Netherbrain[/spoiler], despite all that glorious build-up, goes down in two turns makes the whole thing feel anticlimactic at best and unbelievably disappointing at worst.
[*] While still on the subject of writing, all of the returning characters [i]BG 1[/i] and [I]2[/i] feel like last-minute additions only here to pacify the “[i]BG3[/i] ain't got nothing connecting it to [i]BG 1[/i] and [I]2[/i]!” crowd. [spoiler]Viconia and Sarevok[/spoiler] got absolutely freakin' shafted: both of them got reduced to one-dimensional shades of their former selves. And the fact that Larian didn't hire their original VAs perplexes me: Grey DeLisle/Griffin and Kevin Michael Richardson are still very active in the industry (see: Amazon's 'Invincible'), but here they got inexplicably replaced. What, did Larian blow their entire voice-acting budget on Omni-Man, Satan, and Lady Dimitrescu?
[*] All of your companions, despite hailing from different corners of the planes, feel paradoxically indistinguishable. Why? Because every single one of them has a stock tragic backstory/trauma that you've got to sort out like you're their therapist.
[*] The guard AI is so trigger-happy that it ain't even funny. You'll be accused (even by your allies!) of being in a restricted area or “vandalizing” property because its owner had just destroyed that same property with an errant AoE spell. The Harpers in Act 2 and Gortash's robots and Temple of Bhaal sycophants in Act 3 come to mind here very vividly.
[*] The soundtrack is bland and forgettable; it's almost like the composer's heart wasn't in it. The only three good songs (Nine Blades, Harpy Song, and Raphael's Final Act) play once. Once! Larian, please, I'm begging you: when you make a turn-based game, you gotta make more than two-and-a-half good fight themes! I don't want to listen to the same boom-boom tune over and over again, especially when some of the fights take up to 30 minutes to finish.
[*] [spoiler]Bhaalist[/spoiler] Durge ending. “In [spoiler]Bhaal's[/spoiler] name!” followed by credits and exit to the main menu. What in the unholy blazes of Baator did I just witness? Makes the whole evil playthrough (or just the [spoiler]“dominate the brain” choice – the plot happened because some schmucks decided to dominate the brain[/spoiler]) feel like a waste of time.
[/list]

[b]NITPICKS[/b]
[list]
[*] The game has way too much signposting. Yes, flashing warning lights at the point of no return is important, but every major plot beat first gets thoroughly expounded to you by the relevant party after which you will *always* get a summary of what was just said. Gortash info-dumping (about his super-duper evil plan in front of a crowd that's about to elect him Grand Duke, no less – so long, Lady Immersion!) only for his speech to be vomited back at you by the Narrator/Dream Guardian sold this one for me. These ICYMI summaries happen a whole lot in Act 3.
[*] Level design consists of twisted corridors. Normally, they serve their purpose, but the number of times I had to fight the camera that refused to let me target an enemy standing on the high ground was maddening.
[*] Far too many redundant out-of-combat skill checks. Roll a DC 7 to see that there's a body under the bed when you're inches away from that bed? A character native to Faerûn rolling to think of some of the major gods' portfolios? Really?
[*] Despite the game giving you the option of making a non-binary character, making your character anything but cis will backfire. Spectacularly and quickly. Choosing they/them pronouns leads to all of the NPCs referring to you by what you've got in your pants. Which... naturally, ain't a good look for inclusivity. RIP my transmasc Durge – she/her'ed till of end of their days.
[/list]

To wrap this up: if you don't care about anything else other than the gameplay/combat system, you can get [i]BG3[/i] and have a blast, but if you're looking for a compelling main/side stories and dice rolls that aren't as superfluous, play [i]Disco Elysium[/i].

I've always wanted a "choose your own adventure," or "your choices do matter" type of game. Even though I attempted to find such, nothing really hit the bar for me. I was recommended to play this game by a few friends, and I don't regret my decision in giving it a chance.

I'm not someone who's ever played D&D, or even turn-based games. The game was slightly intimidating at first, and with help from friends, this became a must-have gem in my library.

The characters, dialogue, music, story, art, design, everything were A+. I love how easily immersed I became, because the game encourages you to stop and listen. Your choices do matter and can play a significant role in your outcome. You have all the power, and the game asks you: what will you do with it?

Larian Studios is also a great example of what a company should be: communicative, honest, innovative, and most of all- grateful. The fact that they went out their way (multiple) times to thank their consumers and audience, in a genuine manner, is something that these gaming dev studios need to take note of. They could've stopped with the original release- instead, they continue to update, listen to their consumers, and continuously express appreciation. Yes the game has some bugs, but Larian Studios makes me (and others) confident that they will always find ways to elevate Baldur's Gate 3 and their future endeavors.  No surprise they won multiple awards, and I'm sure the title (and future projects) will follow suit, if they take note in what they achieved with BG3.

This is how you create and garner a committed, loyal and loving audience. Well done.

It's been the first game in a long while I get that excited feeling in the stomach before going home to play, like I did when I was younger. It's definitely an experience that cannot be provided by numbers alone. You can play the game in any way you wish, and a failure in speech is only a failure on paper. It fits the dnd mold that way. The game still continues, the story still stretches. By the time I reached Acts 2 and 3, most major problems had either been resolved or significantly minimized.the narrator (Amelia Tyler) & the voice acting for me is simply perfection. The quality of the voice work elevates the entire experience; without it, I will NEVER play BG3 and simply will watch the game on Twitch rather than playing it myself.After spending 180 hours to 1.5 playthroughs lol, my conclusion is clear BG3 is an absolute must-try (or must-have) game. Its immersive world, engaging choices, and exceptional voice acting make it a standout title in the CRPG genre and GOTY and game of the generation if I can say so myself.

156509503.review:
"You are not alone in this; none of us are."
After completing this magnificent game twice, I can confidently say it is the best RPG I have ever played. However, I want to closely examine the details of the game to articulate my opinion.

Firstly, companions, villains, supporting characters, and cameos—all are amazing. Starting with companions, the most memorable and well-written for me were Astarion, Shadowheart, Karlach, Gale, and Wyll, each with a unique quest that significantly affects the main story, especially Shadowheart, Lae’zel, and Gale. However, the best companion quest belongs to Astarion, firstly because of his charisma and secondly due to the significant dramatic effect the decision at the end of his quest brings upon him. Nonetheless, all characters are not only fantastic to play in a party with but also interesting to chat with, learning their stories and feelings about the situations in the game.

Villains, on the other hand, have fewer memorable characters, but those that are memorable overshadow others. For example, my favorite villains were the pragmatic but charming devil Raphael and the leader with the most tragic backstory, General Ketheric Thorm. They were not only voiced wonderfully but also left a lasting impact on me in both playthroughs—Raphael provided the most memorable fight in the game and pleased me every time he showed up, suggesting cooperation in various ways. Ketheric, on the other hand, demonstrated how broken a man can be in this world, making him the most relatable one among the Dead Three. Additionally, I must mention that on my second playthrough (Resisting Dark Urge), Orin had many new lines and cool dialogue, making him one of the best villains for this path.

There are also cameo characters that can be your allies or foes. For example, possible companions are the old veterans of Baldur's Gate—Minsk and Jaheira. For me, they were just okay, nothing special. However, there were two villain cameos, Sarevok Anchev and Viconia DeVir. Viconia provided a challenging fight, but Sarevok, like Orin, had more lines and was voiced wonderfully. Every line from him filled me with dread, even though as a boss, he wasn't as challenging as Raphael or Viconia.

Speaking of supporting characters, some are memorable, such as Isobel, Dame Aylin, Emperor/Balduran, Orpheos, Volo, Yurgir, Mizora, Alfina (even though I met her only on the second playthrough on Dark Urge, so R.I.P. :( ), Sceleritas Fel, and many more were fun to talk to and help or not help in any matter.

Another thing I want to talk about is gameplay and immersion. Truth be told, initially, I didn't want to play BG3 because of the D&D-based combat. Still, after watching reviews and talking with my friends and colleagues who played it, I bought it, and it was my best purchase of 2023. I didn't understand the turn-based combat at first, but the immersion, lore, story, and interesting characters helped me overcome myself and appreciate the combat. After completing my first playthrough, I immediately started a new one, not only because of the combat but also for reasons I'll explain later in my essay.

I would also like to mention that not only does the story have a huge variety of options, but so does the combat. There are 12 classes, even more subclasses and origins that stack up on each other, creating your own experience of how you want to play. I went for a Wizard/Sorcerer multiclass on my first playthrough, and it was amazing. The design of spells brought me joy, and the flexibility of different spells in battle was fantastic. My second playthrough as a Dark Urge Paladin was incredibly powerful. Maybe it was due to experience and knowledge of what to expect from different bosses, but my god, all bosses except Raphael, Viconia, and Nether Brain were decimated in 1-2 turns, with most of the damage coming from my Paladin tiefling beauty. I can't describe all the complexity of combat now, but I can assure you it would be enjoyable for fans and newcomers alike, like me.

Also, the attention to detail in the game and the quality of the quests show how people put their heart and soul into this game. There are no useless encounters, quests, or conversations in the game. After completing the game, I can say with a clear heart that every dialogue, every side quest is useful in its way. It is either vital to the story, gives you an amazing reward, is entertaining, or even all of the above. As someone with a keen interest in the video game industry and as a person studying to work in that industry, I was overwhelmed by this level of quality. All I can say is, "Bravo Larian, masterclass work!"

The story is a slightly weaker part than everything above due to a lack of drama in some parts. I am not saying it is bad—no, it is good, very good, to be exact. However, a bit more drama in Act 2 or 3 would have made it masterful. Going back to the cliffhanger I left in the sentence above, one thing that made me replay the game was the story variety. Like mentioned before, every origin, class, subclass, decision, and relationship with companions affects the story differently. The only game I've played with this level of variety was Witcher 3, but Witcher couldn't even be compared to Baldur's Gate; that's how unimaginable it is. That's why it was more than worth it to play it for the second time. I explored places I hadn't been to in the first playthrough, completed quests I hadn't finished previously, and got a new ending. It made me tear up, not only because I got Karlach's ending but also because I knew this is it—my adventure has come to an end. The main thing that stands above everything in this story is the real sense of an adventure, epic, full of amazing characters, and a lot of memorable moments.

Lastly, I want to talk about the soundtrack. Well, it is amazing, who would've thought. Borislav Slavov, singers, and the orchestra worked really hard to create such a pleasant soundtrack. Every piece of the game is accompanied by fitting and beautiful songs. My favorite songs throughout my two journeys were Raphael's Final Acts, The Legacy of Bhaal, I Want to Live, Down by the River, Song of Balduran, and many more.

So, this is by far the best game of the 2020 decade, the best gameplay experience of the year, and this magnificent journey with its amazing characters will be engraved in my mind for a long time. Hopefully, I will revisit this game in the upcoming years. I can give nothing less than the best mark for this game, for the astonishing work done to create this masterpiece RPG. You have my undying gratitude, Larian. 
10/10.

157764411.review:
tl;dr - A phenomenal game with a price tag that flies too close to the sun. You could get 5 times the experience of bg3 for half the price.

The more I play this game, the more I realise problems with it. Immediately, I praise it for its incredibly lengthy and open story with multiple routes to take. By that aspect, I'm reminded of games like Detroit: Become Human and Undertale. The gameplay has quite a lot of issues with it, especially coming from the perspective of a TTRPG player. One of the biggest differences between a TTRPG and BG3 is that the game is not on your side at all. It's like having a DM that's trying to find every opportunity to screw you over. With how easy it is to accidentally make a mistake in this game, you're gonna want to quicksave every 5 minutes. That may seem like an exaggeration but that's being generous. For example, if you're playing a Paladin, the game doesn't make the Oaths clear and you could break your Oath with no clue you were doing so. If that happens, you better hope you hit F5 to quicksave or you're gonna need to do a lot of backtracking on an older save.

One thing I'm progressively realising, more and more, is that this game is built on its modding community. I was hesitant to try mods without completing the game, initially. Now that I've tried mods, I could never go back. The amount of quality of life that's completely overlooked and solved by mods is astonishing. The amount of content the mod makers have made for this game is truly incredible, too. 

This is an absolutely phenomenal game, but the one thing pushing this down into a negative review for me is the price tag. There are other games out there that do what Baldur's Gate 3 do best for much cheaper. Detroit: Become Human is half the price, with a similarly impressive story and graphics. Heavy Rain is a quarter of the price. Undertale is roughly a tenth of the price with both its sequels being free. 

What pulls me back into this game is its story and sheer amount of options for customisation. Going through hours of content across 3 different acts several times as different races, classes or even with different motivations or party members makes this a unique experience every time. 

If this game drops in price, buy it. It's phenomenal. Otherwise, if you want a rich story experience with multiple options, try Undertale, Deltarune, Detroit: Become Human, Heavy Rain or many other story and choice heavy games. If you want to experience the game's deep levels of customisation and the combat system, play a D&D fifth edition game with your friends. If you don't have friends but still crave that fifth edition experience, this is the perfect option.

Context: This review was written on 07/02/2024. The English price is £49.99 and the lowest it's ever gone on sale is £44.99. The game hasn't received updates beyond hotfixes for 3 months.

157298074.review:
This is the first review I have ever written on Steam for a game and for good reason. 
There are a lot of games I enjoy, some I've spent upwards of 400 hours playing through (Warhammer 2), yet none come close to what Baldur's Gate 3 did to me. I was reminded of the time where I had just rediscovered Skyrim and sank over 800 hours into it on my Switch or how - when I got Elden Ring - I spent entire nights sleepless, because I just could not put the game down. Baldur's Gate 3 did something similar to me, but even more intense.
Constantly I feel the urge (hehe) to start a new character or reload a safe, because I want to see how a scenario might have turned out had I said something different or went another direction before heading to my objective. I want to hear all the companions' remarks and comments on my dialogue and actions, I want to cheese my way through combat or try it the traditional way, I want to rush through certain dungeons, but then slow down and take in every single minute detail of another. I want to explore, strategize, argue with myself over what choice to take in order to stay truest to my character while not fucking myself over. There are so many things I have in my mind at all times when playing BG3 and that is something no game has managed before to this exact degree.

But to go into more specifics - I love the companions. Astarion starting out as a sarcastic, whiny bitch and then slowly opening up over the progression of the story and making you understand why he's acting like he has throughout your journey. Shadowheart being all mysterious and broody and having problems opening up to you. Lae'zel being mostly just scared and resorting to what years of indoctrination have presented her as a safe haven. Wyll and Karlach both in the end just wanting to do what's right and so on and on.
Minthara, Halsin, Jaheeira and Minsc are all also great followers, but ultimately less important than those named above - and I guess Gale's also there.

And atop that the story is fucking magnificent and even works to incorporate literally any and all of the characters' backgrounds as very central parts to at least one part of the plot.

The combat is extremely fun as well as there are literally uncountable many ways to approach any encounter and do anything from blowing everything up, to stealthily taking enemies out one by one. 

Ah, man- I don't know what else to say, cause at this point I'm just rambling and thinking of new shit to say, because there is just that much positive to say about the game, but I also don't want to blow this review out of proportion, so I'll end it here and tell LITERALLY EVERYONE to play this game, because it's the best to have ever come out during my life time in my opinion - and it's an enrichment to the entire gaming community and scene in general.

The only appeal of this game is the lack of alternatives. When you ostensibly hold a monopoly over D&D-type games, you are going to get good reviews. I have never logged out of this game without feeling either annoyed, stressed, tired, angry, or overwhelmed. I would guess that this is the case even among many who would give this game a positive review.

There are far too many TPK/OTK mechanics in this game which lead to this game being boring. There is no weight to any decision you make. Gameplay is totally designed around you save-scumming. "Choices matter" couldn't be more misleading.

Most of these death mechanics are one-off "gotchas" that result in you dieing because you just "didn't know" which is very shallow gameplay. You walked toward the glowing statue in the middle of the room? Well now you got knocked off the platform and are permadead, guess it's time to save-scum haha but at least you know for the next time!

The characters are equally as shallow as the gameplay. 

When one character has a tragic backstory and is a little evil, it can make for an interesting story/dynamic.

When EVERY character has an overly serious, tropey, tragic backstory and is totally evil and also tries to sleep with anything that breathes, it is extremely boring. Even the CLERIC is an evil shar cultist. 

You cannot have a 'good' playthrough on this game without pissing someone off.

I guess some slack must be given to the writers, as it's difficult to write a character more interesting than yourself.

156587092.review:
Baldur’s Gate 3 isn’t a terrible game, but it’s definitely not the most amazing piece of gaming media to have ever been released like so many people have made it out to be. I suppose people are saying that when comparing it to a lot of the half-assed games other developers have released in recent years, but obviously that’s not that high of a bar to surpass. It’s a finished product with hours of content, sure, but apart from pretty cutscenes, good voice acting, and a few good moments in the story, BG3 doesn’t really have a whole lot going for it. In terms of overall gameplay, quests, and story, the game is very janky, tedious, monotonous, and ultimately... mediocre. 

I won’t talk much about the story to avoid spoilers. It’s alright, but it’s not anything to write home about. It seemed fairly derivative of Divinity: Original Sin 2’s story, with basically the entirety of Act 1 seeming copied and pasted from DOS2’s Act 1. You go down on a crashing ship, get saved by some otherworldly intervention, and then spend the rest of the sequence looking for a way to remove your [strike]source collar[/strike] Illithid tadpole. The similarities continue with the presence of an elusive Big Bad and its cult, an otherworldly and personal guide, and a surprise character from the lore who is now much different than before. Such similarities aren’t inherently bad things- especially since plenty of stories are going to have the same overarching themes and conflicts- but BG3’s story definitely seems like a case of “copying the homework then changing it to look different”. Furthermore, the story starts feeling pretty rushed partway into Act 2, with all the buildup to a certain character tapering off to properly introduce other characters prevalent in Act 3 and then suddenly up the stakes of the situation. Given the way you progress through this game, though, the tonal shift falls flat given how you can dally along however long you want despite everything telling you how bad everything is and how you really have to hurry to save the world now.

Speaking of things feeling rushed, that 100% applies to all the romances in the game. There’s very little buildup and chemistry to such a sudden payoff… even if you haven’t been actively pursuing a relationship. It’s honestly pretty funny, since it takes very little to go from having ordinary conversations with your companions to them suddenly confessing their love for you and wanting to bang. Hell, having consistent interactions with them isn’t even required for that to happen: I’m still laughing about how surprised Halsin seemed that I didn’t reciprocate his feelings for me, saying that I “tended to [his] needs at camp not as a host but as a lover”… when I only talked to him like, five times, and ONLY for a couple of story-related quests, NEVER in a way even remotely flirtatious, and even AFTER I was already in a relationship with Shadowheart. Never even used the dude in my active party a single time!

Your companions are probably the strongest part of the game. They all have interesting and enjoyable questlines and personalities, and it’s fun seeing the way they react not only to you and your choices, but to each other while you’re out adventuring. Even the companions I wasn’t that interested in adventuring with seemed like solid characters, so there’s certainly an aspect of replayability just to be able to get to know them and see their questlines through to the end. Unfortunately… that would involve playing the game again.

BG3’s gameplay is… not good. Dice rolls don’t really translate well into video game format. It works in DnD and other tabletops because they’re a collaborative storytelling and roleplaying experience. The DM or other players can always make your fails interesting, pick up on your slack, or, if worse comes to worst, find a way to bail you out. In game format, you're just fucked since the outcomes are predetermined, usually with a failure leading to combat or you just wasting your turn. Even succeeding at rolls isn’t all that interesting, since again, the outcomes are predetermined, and usually just boil down to things like getting what you want, getting ignored while trespassing, or lowering the price of something. Not very interesting in the end even if it’s satisfying seeing you passed the roll. 

Combat, especially when there are several enemies around, feels like such a slog, and sometimes even lags as if an NPC suddenly gained sentience and is deliberating on what action to take. Movement feels slow and limited, with there being multiple instances where a perfectly reachable space or enemy CAN’T be reached just… because. You especially feel limited as a spellcaster, not because of limited spell slots, but because so many of your spells are niche and situational or concentration-based, which limits the kinds of spells you’d even be willing to use. It’s similar for your Feats as well; you only get to choose three of them in the entire game, and so many of them are, again, niche and inferior to other feats with clearer and broader upsides in their use. 

Inventory management is a pain, especially with the overabundance of pointless items, potions, and scrolls you’ll never need to use on a regular playthrough. Reminds me of why I only ever did Lone Wolf playthroughs in DOS2, because having to manage four clunky and cluttered inventories was a chore. The same applies to radial management for your skills and spells, at least if you’re playing on controller.

Finally, your choices and progression… Ultimately, it didn’t really seem to matter much what I did. I really hate how often I could quickly find the solution to a problem or a particular quest only for the characters involved to talk or act as if I hadn’t by giving me information I already knew about HOURS ago or saying that this or that thing needs to be done. Your choices also don’t really shape the world and story as you move through it. Even at the very end, you can just “choose your ending”, be it the “good” ending or “bad” ending. The only things that will change during the “good” ending will be your companions depending on how you went about their personal quests. Which alright, I guess, that’s cool, but it’s disappointing to see that the two main endings are practically the same with some minor variations.

Also, the character creator sucks and is super limited and ugly (especially for males), which is surprising given how most of the other characters you meet- male or female- look pretty decent.

Chore. That’s really the best way to describe playing this game. Usually when I’m out doing class work or working out, by the end I’m thinking, “Man, can’t wait to get home so I can kick back and relax to some Cyberpunk/Fallout/FFXIV.” With BG3, my only thoughts by Act 2 were, “Oh God, I really don’t want to play this game anymore, but I do want to finish the story and get it over with.” By the time I did finish the game, my reaction wasn’t one of feeling satisfied I had finished a good game, but relieved I was finally done playing it. Just like I’m relieved I’m finally done writing this unnecessarily long review lmao.

158067456.review:
The game is one of the greatest I have ever played, this tops Skyrim for me. So I would like to write a complete review of this game. Since the game has respected my time, I shall respect it with a review!!

My advice to anyone playing this game for the first time would be to watch 3 or 4 combat and/or tips and trick videos, stay away from viewing OP build guides (atleast for your first 2 playthroughs) and 
MOST IMPORTANTLY engage in writing out a background for your character, impose some restrictions on them, "Eg: due to having their entire family killed by goblins, Tav has a hatred for goblins and prefers to kill them before even speaking to them", stuff like that, I did it and I felt this improved my experience many fold.

But most importantly, all playstyles are viable and play it in your way, any way you like

A) The Combat: 

a) As this was my first CRPG I had a lot of problems with the combat. The tutorial IMO did not do enough for teaching me the basics of what spell saves are or difficulty class is or what is attack rolls and that it is different from damage rolls, etc.
b) After maybe 50 hours into the game, the gameplay began to flow very well. You have so many different ways to defeat your foes, it is crazy. The best part is, apart from a few instances, whenever I thought up a new way to beat my enemies, it surprisingly worked!! Command them to drop their weapon, collect the dropped weapons and then watch as they helplessly try to hit you with their fist? Done. Put them in an AOE concentration spell, and make them unable to move and watch as they slowly suffocate to dead? Say no more. Become a wild beast and maul them to death? The lemons are there, squeeze them as hard as you want! 
c) The magic felt lacking in some aspects though, I felt there were too many concentration spells and not enough fire and forget spells. 
d) I have not yet played a melee character (unless you count an owlbear as one) so I cannot speak for them, but as a magic character, the game was pretty fun.
e) I played my playthrough on tactitian difficulty and O boy, the game was challenging till the end! The difficulty is well paced. The fights were nail biting (unless you save scum) and every moment was a fun kind of challenge. I can say that, there are definite OP builds in the game, but I suggest you not look it up until you have beat the game atleast 2 times!
f) The best part I liked about the combat is that your party of 4 is not special at all (I played my first playthrough denying the worm). Everyone in this game who is of the same level as you, has equal amount of power as you and wont hesitate to utilize powerful spells and tactics against you (except for maybe the rogues). It makes you feel that if you are careless in battle you or multiple teammates might fall.
g) Carrying on from the last point, the death of your companions does not really feel special. There are so many ways to revive fallen heroes that death never felt like a threat, more of a disadvantage in the current combat situation. I really hope there is more weight to keeping teammates alive in the game, rather than just letting them die and reviving them.
h) Dont worry about making the wrong choice in the character creator, all classes are viable and can be used to finish the game. Play your way and enjoy!!

B) Story: (Does not contain side quests and character quests) 

a) The story overall is a base "Save the World" story with a few twists, nothing very special, but nothing to scoff at either. The last act, ACT 3, dragged on and became boring for a bit, but towards the end the pace picks up again and you can feel the adrenaline rush as it did in the previous acts.
b) The first Act was by far the best Act. They kept up the mystery throughout the first Act extremely well, and I could never have imagined there would be so much to do in this Act, and there is obviously more than meets the eye in the first act.

Characters 

a) This is the segment, the game that shines the most in. Every character has their own motivations and decisions. You will feel like each character that joins you is looking out for their interests. They actually feel like living breathing humans (or whatever race they are). They chime in with their inputs in conversations, they dislike some of your actions and like others.
b) Apart from your companions, the people who live in this world feel lively when first seeing them, obviously the charm dies a bit after hearing them for the 5th time, but it is really cool. The main city is bustling with people talking to others about their daily lives, how some adventurers dont want to live in a brothrel because other inns are occupied, how a gnome is being gifted a sex session from a brothel by his friends and how he is extremely shy about it. The world seems lived in and makes you want to save it all the more.
c) Side quest Characters are not just quest givers. Often their fate is determined by what you do and sometimes you meet these people in later areas and it is a really pleasant surprise!

World

a) The world has been built excellently. This I believe is another pillar of this game. The world is divided into acts and you cannot travel to Act 1 or Act 2 locations once you step into Act 3. Each world is massive and has a wealth of new discoveries to be made and surprises to be found if you look hard enough.
b) The world changes you make are permanent, meaning anything that is looted will remain looted and anyone who is killed will remain killed. This makes you feel a sense of belonging to this world, when you go past a battleground, you are reminded of the fights you had there!

All in all, this game has been an excellent one and I no doubt will play more of this for many months to come, I really hope Larian releases modder resources like Bethesda and CDPR, so the talented modding community can build more amazing awesome stuff in an already amazing game. 
This game has so much to offer and so many stories to tell that, this game truely cannot be finished after a single playthrough.

156088086.review:
There is a fun game underneath its many issues, but this is a warning to prospective players. This game was a buggy, unstable mess of poor performance on 1.0 release, even on high end hardware. Some improvements and fixes have been made since then, but the game is still not in an acceptable release state. The state of this game is comparable to Cyberpunk 2077 in its launch window. I expected better from a game coming out of two years in Early Access.

My Steam hours played of 170 is deceptive, because my in-game save file is about half that at about 80 hours. There is not a quest, encounter, NPC, or party member that did not break or have significant issues during my run. In a single save file, I had to replay almost every second of this game. A quest or encounter or NPC interaction would break, and I was forced to reload a previous save. If that didn't fix the issue, I'd keep going back to earlier and earlier saves until I found one that wasn't yet bugged or with a branching path that worked. Many issues were never solved, and there were quests, plotlines, encounters and interactions I was unable to see through.

And these issues are present from the very first moments of the game and throughout, not just in Act 3. In the current patch, many issues persist, and performance today remains poor on a range of hardware throughout the game.

That said, the character and class options are very impressive, and combat is a lot of fun. There is a very cool fantasy tactics game buried underneath its many issues.

Wait for this game to improve in performance and fix its bugs and glitches. There's a fun game buried underneath this myriad of issues. For those with a high tolerance for buggy and broken games, it can still be a good time. But it's not worth the money yet. Wait for Baldur's Gate 3 to be fixed and go on sale.

157276301.review:
The negative rating is not because the game is bad, but because it is overrated and disappointing.

TL;DR If you want the complex world interactions in combat - play Divinity: Original Sin 2, as it is better at that than BG3. If you want a great story driven game - play Witcher 3. If you are nostalgic about Baldur's Gate games - play BG2. If you are in love with the great work of the voice actors - might be better to just watch YouTube videos with them.

I think that the voice acting here is awesome. Could not agree more with the Astarion actor getting the Best Performance reward, other actors are hardly far behind. The eagles in the monastery are totally irrelevant for the plot and also have only a few lines, but that is a way better voice acting than many main characters have in games.

I am also very glad to see an RPG game with so much funding. Hope, there are going to be other RPG games on the same level of funding. Unfortunately, there are plenty of issues.

[b]Bugs[/b]. They are inevitable and, hopefully, they are going to be fixed. But right now bugs result in plot holes, in failed honor runs and in generally plenty of frustration. So worth mentioning.

[b]Story issues[/b]. I assume that a lot of hype around the game is because of the fully voiced dialogues and the attached expectations of a great narrative and story. Maybe people think it is a new Witcher 3. Unfortunately, it is not. The story is good in act 1 and act 2. The second act could have been a great ending for the whole game. Unfortunately, there is act 3 with its dumber villains and unimaginative resolutions to the mysteries. The companion arcs are disappointing - as if the writers wanted some of them to suffer no matter what just because. The story conclusion of not being able to face the last boss without [spoiler]an illithid[/spoiler] doesn't have any real justification, feels like a forced utter garbage. The was no reason at all to use a prominent historical figure ([spoiler]Balduran[/spoiler]) the way they did, it serves no purpose. And do not forget the bugs that just deprive you of parts of the story through the whole game.

[b]Bad designs[/b].
[list]
[*]Rests. The game wants you to rest. A lot. If you do not take long rests all the time, you miss parts of the story and won't be able to progress some quests. But the same time the game punishes you for resting - at the beginning it seems that you just won't have enough camp resources to rest enough, also resting after triggering some events or quests leads to automatic resolution (quite disappointing) of those events. So it feels that whatever you do - you are going to miss some story. An awful feeling for a story-driven game.

[*]"Entering a different region". Sometimes the game forces a long rest if you travel to a different region, other times it doesn't. Sometimes prominent quests in the current region are going to automatically resolve in detrimental ways if you travel to a different region, sometimes they won't. There is no consistency or clarity. It negatively impacts exploration in a game, where exploration is supposed to be a big part.

[*]Tons of useless containers and loot. If you worry that you might miss some useful loot - you have reasons for that. And that also means that you are going to spend hours of your time going through useless jars or boxes. It doesn't add to the game, just wastes your time. My advice - just use a guide listing all the notable loot and then ignore the rest. But that is not a good sign for a game. And if you need gold - just pickpocket vendors.

[*]Approval system. If you do not have enough approval from your companions, at certain points of their story they might just leave. Or you might be forced to kill them. Or they would make a choice affecting the story in regrettable ways. So you want to get their approval. So you spend hours swapping your companions for each dialogue, as only those in your active party have a chance to get approvals during you questing. Again, following a guide is very useful here. And again, it is a bad sign for any game.

[*] Honor mode. Honor mode is not just an ironman. It is also an increase in difficulty, as some mechanics change. And because bosses get new abilities. So you have a mode that doesn't provide much room for error. And when you come to a boss you see the boss having an unexpected new ability that you were not able to prepare for (unless you, you know, follow guides instead of playing the game), which might result in a loss of dozens of hours of your play time. And do not forget the bugs that might just screw your run. If you want the achievement - just follow some speed running guides. That might allow you to beat the game in an hour or two.

[*]Unable to go to camp. End of both act 2 and of act 3 you lose the access to your camp. Which means no long resting, so no chance to restore spell slots etc, but also means you can't switch party members. End of act 3 throws meat waves of enemies at you and you can't risk using your abilities, as you do not know when you are going to really need them later. And end of act 2 I had no idea that it was the moment [spoiler]Gale[/spoiler] was getting ready to, so I didn't even have him in my party.

[*][spoiler]Jaheira[/spoiler] end of act 2. When I finally got a chance to invite into my party a certain prominent druid lady, I had no idea that a) there was going to be another chance to invite her and that b) inviting her end of act 2 means being stuck with her through the rest of act 2. She can't be told to stay at the camp and at the same time she doesn't have any special interactions through the act 2 finale. I am really glad it was at least possible to respec her into whatever I needed in my party, but it was a bad workaround.
[list]

157525490.review:
First impressions:   Disappointed

Honestly, if I had known this was click-to-move with turn-based combat I would never have bought it. For me, both those control modes are big time immersion destroyers. Constantly manipulating a floating camera to try to figure out where you are, where you are going, and what's going on around you is unnatural and often disorienting, as apposed to simply looking around yourself in the first person perspective like you do naturally (whether its true first person, through your own eyes; or third/first person over your shoulder.)  And turn based combat, as opposed to real time, is just plain tedious.

Okay, so admittedly that's more a critique of click-to-move with turn-based combat games in general than it is of Baldur's Gate 3 specifically. The game environment is gorgeous.  The character creation, character races, character sub-races and sub-classes give you endless options and is a lot of fun just to browse through. The game is pleasingly narrated where appropriate and the cut scenes seem to be well paced. Finally, the nod to classic D20 D&D is kind of cute and fun.

En fin; I'm disappointed because this game simply is not going to engender the kind of addictive immersion I look for in an RPG, but it's still worth playing on a more casual level.


Edit - 

Now six and a half hours into the game and I'm requesting a refund from Steam. I tried hard, wanted to like it, but the reality is I'm spending more time trying to wrestle the camera into submission than I am enjoying the game. And to add insult to injury the turn based combat just feels like it's running slow as molasses, both issues together make the game simply aggravating.  If you are a fan of turn based combat and third person, unhingd camera games you may find a way to forgive these shortcomings as the game is gorgeous and the story compelling.

142502377.review:
I had no intention of playing Baldur's Gate 3; I barely played 1 and missed 2.  And I just don't have 200 hours to sink into an 80 GB RPG at my age.  I enjoyed Divinity: Original Sin and couch co-op'd with my wife in D:OS 2, but we have a mortgage and a dog and no time.

Then I read the Tweet.  You know the one: the prominent game developer who said that we cannot allow Larian to define our expectations of RPGs.  Oh, really?  I immediately bought the game and spent hours downloading it out of pure, unadulterated spite.

I am 3 hours in.  Three.  I am blown away.  I spent the first hour creating my character.  I pulled out my Dungeons & Dragons 5th Edition Player's Handbook and marveled at what BG3 had enabled me to do - this is the full blown 5E character creation.  The maniacs at Larian  took Divinity: Original Sin and made it into D&D 5E, full stop.  Amazing.

And then I played for a couple of hours.

I haven't fallen in love with a game like this since Dragon Age: Origins and there is so much more depth to BG3 in the short time I've played.  Case in point: I found a lockpick, broke into a crypt, looted a burial site and was promptly incinerated by a flame trap over a greased floor.  Thank you, Larian, for reminding me of the F5 key.

The graphics are amazing.  The voice work is the best.  The cut scenes are riveting and that's usually when I go make another whisky!  The sound design is unbelievable.  Why am I noticing sound design?  I don't care about sound design!

I've misclicked so many times.  There's so much to click!  I've died in so many ways.  There are so many ways to die!  There are so many bugs, but I don't even care because in a game as complex and deep as this, you're going to experience lots and lots of FUN. 

Larian, you've done it.  You've made a game so incredible that other developers are banding together to warn us not to play your magnum opus or we won't enjoy the next Stranger Things Click Quest game or whatever garbage they're shoveling out.  

I cannot wait to spend days in Baldur's Gate 3.


* Edit 8/1/2023 after ~60 hours *

Since this review got some attention, let me give you an update after about 60 hours of Early Access.  My initial review is, obviously, hyperbolic, but that was my real-time reaction to finding a truly great game in a genre and style that I thought had been abandoned by game producers who are more interested in games as service, micro-transactions and shooters.

The best review of BG3 I could give is that this is the game I've been hoping for since Dragon Age: Origins.  I play games for systems, not so much story, and I really like both the systems and the story of this game.  If I really like a game, I look forward to starting over and trying something new (I play XCOM 2 and Dwarf Fortress a little bit.)  This game also scratches that itch, which seems strange to say about a story-driven RPG, but it really is a game that encourages you to experiment.

As it stands, on the verge of release, this game is a 10/10 for me and in my pantheon of favorites.

(I don't work for Larian or have anything to do with them other than playing D:OS.)

77820979.review:
EDIT: 

I created a video review for Patch #8. If you want to check it out I put a link at the end of this review. I know a lot of people found this initial review helpful and I hope my most recent one can help people decide whether or not they want to buy the game! 

So should you get Baldur's Gate 3? If you really like Larian RPG games then probably yeah, it's a lot like their other games with a few major differences that might make you not enjoy the game: 

1) The skills don't have CDs like in other games, they're based on 5E D&D so they're based on your class, so your class selection is very important and you'll need a balanced party.

2) If you're big into D&D games like me you might be frustrated at some of the Larian game mechanics, like Ray of Frost leaving ice beneath the feet of enemies and similar spells leaving fields on the ground that debuff or damage targets. Ray of Frost is the biggest offender since slipping on ice ends your turn, or your opponents turn making it the best mage cantrip for its RNG value. 

Is this game a sequel to Baldur's Gate 1 and 2? 

No, so far it seems like it has nothing to do with the other Baldur's Gates game besides the fact you're trying to get to Baldur's Gate to some degree but can't because monsters are fucking around in the countryside, as per usual. Your character is also not a Bhaalspawn so I'm not sure why they called it Baldur's Gate 3 when more accurately it should be like: Baldur's Gate: The Mind Flayering or something similar. 

Does the game run well? 

Depends on your machine, mine is fairly powerful and with the game ready Nvidia Driver the game runs smooth, however textures kinda pop in weirdly, the game is in Early Access so it's expected that the graphics aren't full up to snuff yet. 

Does the combat feel good? 

Yeah, it feels pretty good they got the 5E stuff in game to work really well and they added in special weapon attacks that make a big difference. The Combat is deadly, but fair and you have loads of options to subvert encounters and crush your enemies. Beyond that it's not a big murder hobo affair either you do murder many things but I was surprised when I actually found some friendly monsters who'd normally be murder hobo fodder. Larian also wisely shot the alignment system of D&D in the head behind a shed which was a good move since 5E doesn't really use that system very much anyways. I find the AI however has a hard time handling stealth attacks, where I can sometimes get three free stealth attacks against monsters if I have my rogue hidden well, perhaps that's a bug or a reward for good positioning I can't say. 

How is the Story? (Don't worry, no spoilers)

Story is pretty fine and the characters you meet along the way are interesting. Some are a bit hostile towards you but due to the situation you find yourself in I think it's 100% natural that your party will be distrustful towards each other and your character. However I found that even the more nasty characters do warm up to you quickly, or at the very least treat you as a decent person. I read some reviews after playing where reviewers complained that the party ALWAYS hated you. But I only ever felt that one NPC hated me, and now after a few hours into the game they talk to me as an ally and have even confided into me about some of their own secrets making me feel like it's something that could easily become a true friendship. One praise I'll give it that others will call negative is that some persuasion options might not be good ideas. Please use your common sense, you might not want to tell sensitive things about your situation to certain people or even if you pass your check it might have a negative outcome, in this case passing the check makes a really bad situation a bit less bad. You also get special dialogue options due to some special magical powers you get rather early on in the game though I'll avoid calling them by name because that could be a spoiler which give you OP persuasion options that you cannot fail, however I like that the game implies that by using these powers you can get some negative backlash, these options even let you learn extra details about certain characters that share your condition though I have opted not to use them since I assume it will worsen my relationship with the character. The only downside of conversations is that in single player you can't change who is talking to perform skill checks. I had a Dex check in a conversation to pick a lock but couldn't let the rogue do his job to pick the lock. There was also lacking a dialogue option of me just using the key I had on me to unlock the shackles the guy was trapped in. The animations in conversation are also fairly stiff looking and your character only has a few stances they take, they're kinda annoying and I hope they add more variety to them. 

So how good is the game in Early Access? 

I'd say pretty good, you get a large area to explore and the characters are varied and the story interesting if a bit high fantasy, though I feel Baldur's Gate was also High Fantasy, I will say I'm not a fan of certain named characters existing in the world like Volo who I found, but I was happy to learn you can also mindlessly murder such refferences and rob their dead caracasses with only minimal consequences (I bribed a guard like 200 gold after I killed Volo and stole all of his swag, it was super worth I'd recommend murdering Volo in every game he's in.)  Beyond that I'd say the game is on the right track to be a cool RPG, though the game requires patience if you want to avoid murder hoboing, the game gives most characters even goblins actual names which makes talking to them and learning their secrets worthwhile, I'd recommend talking to as many people as your patience can handle to solve problems non-violently since some fights are nearly unwinnable. Also don't forget to scout around with your rogue to find shenanigans to cheese encounters and make sure you're not about to walk into a hornets nest.

Patch 8 Review: https://youtu.be/aukz9SodB44
